text:
I debated trying these for a long time before I finally did it.  I was almost positive they were going to be too weird for us!  I give this a 4 instead of a 5 because I made half with black beans and half with kidney beans and the black beans were much better!  Also, mashing the beans after they're in the skillet is a real pain.  Next time I'll mash them first.  I was worried that it was going to be too much cumin and chili powder, but used all the spices just as the recipe suggested and it was the perfect contrast against the subtle sweetness of the potatoes.  Next time I'll use a little more cheese in each burrito.  Served with sour cream.

text:
We loved these & thought they were far from bland. I didn't exactly follow the recipe though. Some spices, particularly curry, cumin & chile powder, need to be sauteed a bit to help release their flavors. So I sauteed my onion for a few minutes, added the garlic (didn't want to cook it too long as it turns bitter), then a  couple of minutes later, added the cumin, chile & cayenne....allowing them to heat for a minute or two. Thsi really pulls the flavor out & makes a big difference.  I used black beans (rinsed & drained & only mashed enough to beak up the beans) instead of kidney beans & I used vegetable broth instead of water, only adding enough to make it the consistency that I wanted.  I used a mexican blend cheese, dark brown spicy mustard & just mixed my mashed sweet potatoes into the bean mixture instead of loading them separately into the burritos. Once assembled, I gave the burritos a light spray w/ olive oil cooking spray, just enough to fake them out & make them think they had been fried. ;o) Served them w/ fresh mango slices & avocado slizes, sprinkled w/ lime & salt. Brigadiero's (from this site) for dessert. I froze the leftovers on a cookie sheet. I'll wrap them separately in plastic wrap & then put them in a freezer bag.  Thansk for a wonderful recipe Karena!

text:
I recently became a vegetarian and I was looking for a good pre-race meal that would provide my body with the energy needed during a triathlon.  This recipe fits the bill!  As the recipe makes 8-10 depending on what size tortilla you use, I have shared these with several of my cycling and triathlete friends and EVERYONE of them has asked for the recipe.  I only made a few changes to this recipe.  I used 1 can black beans, 1 can pinto beans and 1 cup frozen corn as my bean mixture.  Mash the beans with a potato masher prior to adding the corn for better texture.  I also substituted 8in multigrain low carb tortillas for the flour tortillas, as well as 2% sharp cheddar cheese instead of mild cheddar.  Last, but not least, I put a tablespoon of light sour cream on my burrito after it is heated and ready to eat.  These burritos keep very well.  After cooking them in the oven, I let them cool then wrap each one in a paper towel and freeze in a zip lock bag.  To reheat, just remove from bag, leave in paper towel, and heat in microwave for 2 minutes.  These are just fabulious!!!

text:
Very good and very healthy. Flavours were just right. Like other reviewers, I used black beans in place of kidney beans and left them quite chunky when I mashed them. I baked the sweet potatoes and scooped them out and mashed them very smooth with salt and pepper. I used reduced fat old cheddar and whole wheat tortillas. Served with shredded lettuce and chopped tomatoes, green onions and green peppers and light sour cream. We both loved them. They are quite large, I couldn't finish mine; next time I may make them in the 6-inch tortillas. I froze ten of them, and both my boyfriend and I are looking forward to taking them for lunches! Many thanks for the recipe!


*UPDATE*
Just a quick note on reheating the frozen burritos...It works perfectly in the oven from frozen. 30 mins wrapped in foil at 350, them 15 mins unwrapped to crisp them up. Better than when I first made them!

text:
5 Star Concept - 3 Star Execution. There is no place for water in this recipe and including  it wrecked it for the unwitting as reported in their reviews. The correct way to make this recipe is to cook kidney beans from dry goods. 1 lb. makes 6 cups. They will be perfect and ready without mashing or water. 3 large yams skinned, cooked (13 minutes in microwave in Pyrex pot with water) should make 6 cups – mash in a big stock pot on low heat. Make seasoning as a sauce by using exact ingredients plus 2 squirts of Sriracha and 2 tbls of sweet chili sauce and one tbls safflower oil. The end result will be mildly spicy by American standards. To make spicier, add more chili powder, cayenne, and Sriracha sauce in suggested proportions. Pour the sauce evenly on top of the beans in the skillet and stir. 4 tbls high heat safflower is best oil for this recipe. Also, 12 oz of cheese is required. Type of Cheddar is not called out. Sharp is best for this recipe – Mexican blend will work. This recipe will produce exactly the stated dozen 10” burritos. Thus, it will produce (10) 12” burritos (12” flour tortillas are the best value at Costco). If you prepare dish to these specs you will have a fab meal and leftovers while realizing the full potential of the concept, which is excellent.

I make this recipe all the time - it's become a staple in my household. Wonderful!  I would recommend using a potato masher to mash the beans, as this is the most time-consuming part. I also scale the recipe down to make 5 burritos (1 can beans, 1 can sweet potatos, 1/4 onion).

text:
Thank you Karena for sharing this recipe.  I made it as per the recipe, except, I cut the ingredients in half, as this makes a large amount.  The spice level for me was just right, as I like to taste the other ingredients in the recipe and not overpower them with heavy spices.  As my tastes are not the same as yours, I will probably make a few changes, the next time I make this and there will be a next time.  Possibly a different type of bean and try a different cheese, like pepper jack for a kick. I don't normally write reviews for the recipes on here, but I finally felt like voicing my opinion.  I feel that some of the reviews, on this site, not just on this recipe, would be better left off.  Especially the ones that totally re-write a recipe.  My advise to all members, is to keep in mind a quote that I read from Chef Michael Smith.  He wrote " Recipes are how one cook shares ideas with another cook! They're just words on paper; a guideline, a starting point from which to improvise"   These words are absolutely true.  Every recipe on this site, will have alterations done to it, to suit each persons own tastes.  A few tweaks mentioned are good, but if your are going to re-write it...submit your own. Thanks again Karena, and to all the other cooks that have the guts to submit their recipes for us to enjoy.

text:
I am always a bit skeptical when trying "vegetarian" recipes.    I was raised a vegetarian and I love good vegetarian food, not just “vegetarian” food.  There is a difference!  These are delicious!  If I had a restaurant these burritos would defiantly be on the menu under the "Really Good Vegetarian Food" section!  Even my husband who does not enjoy vegetarian food really likes them.**UPDATE** OH MY GOODNESS GRACIOUS!!!! 5 ***** AFTER MY MODIFICATIONS!!!!    I FOUND A NEW WAY TO ENJOY THESE!!! I SAUTEED 2 CUPS FINELY CHOPPED ONION UNTIL TRANSLUCENT IN A LITTLE OIL.  THEN I ADDED BLACK BEANS 39 OZ OF THEM (I HAD A 15 OZ AND A 24 OZ CAN) . I MASHED THE BEANS TO RESEMBLE GROUND BEEF, ABOUT 50/50. THEN I ADDED A PKG OF TACO SEASONING B/C I WAS PRESSED FOR TIME AND A LITTLE WATER ABOUT 3/4 CUP (EYEBALL IT).  I BAKED 4 LARGE SWEET POTATOES MASHED THEM AND ADDED CINNAMON (YOU WONT BELIEVE HOW GOOD IT IS TILL YOU TRY IT) (A LOT OF MEXICAN DISHES ADD CINNAMON)I PUT EQUAL PARTS BEAN MIXTURE AND POTATO MIXTURE INTO SOFT TORTILLAS (THEY WERE SOFT ENOUGH OUT OF THE PACKAGE SO I DIDN'T HAVE TO WARM THEM TO GET 'EM TO BEND . . . BE CHOOSY WHEN BUYING THEM!) I WRAPPED THEM LIKE A PRESENT AND FRIED 3 OF THEM IN A PAN W/ A BIT OF OIL AND FROZE THE REST ON A COOKIE SHEET TILL FIRM AND PLACED THEM IN A BAG IN THE FREEZER.  THIS RECIPE MAKES ABOUT 18. AFTER FRYING THEM I TOPPED THEM W/ CHEESE SALSA AND SOUR CREAM YUM YUM!!!! 5 STARS WITH MY ALTERATIONS *****

text:
Finally... FINALLY! I made these today! Only been about a year since I saved the dang recipe! LOL! I cut the recipe in half after I looked at the recipe ingredients and thought wow - it's only me eating them! not the Canadian Armed Forces along with me! (but boys - you know I would feed you if I could!) ANYWAY, these are all they are hyped up to be and then some!  I did use Black Beans in place of kidney as I was out of kidney and noticed others had either half and half'd them with kidney or used black beans alone...I prefer the black beans personally over kidney anyday.  I did cut WAY back on the water though, probably a mere 1/4 cup as it just seemed like WAY too much liquid for all that was going on in the pan and I skipped the soy sauce altogether as I do not use it (too salty)....I also used 6-inch tortillas and after halfing the recipe, got 7 small burritos out of the deal, served with fat-free sour cream, this actually makes a pretty good 'waist' friendly meal with going really, really light on the cheese and using w/w, low-carb tortillas like I did...kudos to Karena, you definitely have a winner here!

text:
Very good!  I took the advice of others and made the following changes:  black beans instead of kidney, only mashed 1/2 of them, I only needed about 1/4 to 1/2 cup water rather than the 2 cups called for, added about a cup of corn, added about 3 oz cream cheese to the sweet potato mash, and added cilantro with the cheese.  My husband put sour cream on his at the table.  I warmed my wraps in the microwave & just served that way, no oven needed.  I did make some in the oven but I felt the flavor was much better just right off the stove.  My husband loved it and this will go into our regular cooking rotation and I'll be serving it to guests soon!  This is by far the best sweet potato burrito recipe I've ever tried.  YUM!

text:
My husband & I love this recipe and I don't even like sweet potatoes! Over the year we have made a few changes:
Use 1 can kidney beans, 1 can of corn (drained), 1 cup of water, 2 cooked potatoes, and 6 tortillas. After heating the onions/beans and adding the potatoes, we then add the water, bit by bit until the mixture is smooth. Sometimes it does not take the whole cup of water. We also put the cheese inside the burrito and put sour cream on top when it's done.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been eyeballin' this recipe for quite some time.  It seemed intriguing... but mustard and soy sauce?... Really?  I finally gave it a try this week.  After all, 1000+ reviewers can't be wrong... right?    I.FELL.IN.LOVE.  Naturally, I changed things up a bit.  I sliced my sweet potatoes into 1/4 inch thick slices, tossed them in some oil, cumin, and kosher salt, placed them on parchment paper on a cookie sheet, and baked them at a 450 degrees, flipping them once, until they were nice and speckled brown.  I didn't mash the sweet potatoes at all but put them in the burrito with the other ingredients as is.  Didn't change much else to the recipe, except "cooking" the cumin, cayenne, and chili powder, which is pretty much a necessity.  I also added some fresh jalapeno, cilantro, and green onion as well.  I've made it twice this week for friends and roommates.  EVERYONE is enamored with these most excellent burritos!

Great recipe! I served it with Newman's Own pineapple salsa and it was fantastic! I scaled the recipe down to three servings and it fed two adults and a child w/ left overs! I did mix black beans w/ the kidney (equal parts) and I left the potatoes and the beans a little chunky instead of mashing the whole thing. Next time the only changes I will make is to not mash any of it (the texture adds to it) and leaving out the cheese (I ended up scraping mine off, I didn't think it needed it).

text:
I make this dish every couple of weeks, wrap the individual burritos, and freeze them to eat for lunch or dinner on busy days. It's so easy to pop them in the microwave, and it's definitely more nutritious than a frozen dinner! I like to use wholegrain mustard in mine and I replace the kidney beans with black beans. To make these even healthier I use whole wheat tortillas. Don't waste time making sure the beans are thoroughly mashed, and sautee the spices with the onion to bring out the flavors more.

text:
I had everything to make this (really sorry I waited so long) but didn't feel like making beans from dried.  Remembered I had some overdone navy beans in the freezer.  I used those and since they were all mashed added a can of Ranch beans with jalapeños.  Cubed and steamed my sweet potatoes and mixed them in like that instead of mashing. I really wanted more heat so used a can of Rotel instead of any water, will use extra hot Rotel next time.  Used in burritos, as dip for chips, as topping for tostadas.  All VERY good.  Skipped the cheese half the time and didn't miss it at all.

text:
I absolutely LOVED this recipe! I made all the changes recommended by previous reviewers. I added green peppers, added my spices before the beans, used brown mustard, used black beans along with the kidney beans, added a cup or so of frozen corn, and mashed the beans before adding them. I also added about 2T of taco seasoning, and didn't need anywhere near 2 C of water. I served with vegan non soy cheese, spinach, and salsa. I would definitely make this on a regular basis!! It made ALOT though, so I will probably shorten the recipe for future use.

text:
I made a double batch of these and instead of baking them threw them straight into the freezer. Being a student, it was the perfect solution to avoiding greasy over-priced meals at the cafeteria- it would defrost in my school bag over the course of the morning, and was ready for the microwave by lunch! Do season according to your tastes- I needed a little more kick to mine. The name is accurate, these are addictive (the flavour combination is captivating) but the texture is a little too uniform and dense to earn it a perfect rating, in my opinion. Baking them would no doubt help with this, adding a little crispness.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is wonderful! Thanks for a great recipe! 

OI used only 2 tablespoons of soy sauce. I made it super easy by using 2 cans of refried black beans and 2 of whole black beans. Didn't have to mash anything. Used no water and can't imagine why it would be used. Didn't even use the water from the beans. Also, cooking sweet potatoes is very simple when you cut them into one inch slices and cook them for 30 minutes or less at 400 degrees. I lightly coat the slices with olive oil and a little sea salt. The skins slide right off after baking. used 2 fat pinches of the cayenne pepper too, and cooked the bean mixture just a couple of minutes after adding the spices. I used Dijon mustard!

The way I like to finish these is by putting extra cheese on top of the burritos and covering lightly with foil, then heating for 25 minutes or so at 350 degrees. Make sure the foil does't stick to the cheese before heating.

Display Name:
Courtnes

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I debated making this recipe for a while because the addition of soy sauce and mustard was a little off-putting--when I finally made the recipe I omitted them. I definitely didn't make this recipe as specified--I used it more as a concept more than a guide. I also wanted to make a much smaller amount since there are only 2 of us--12 burritos is a bit much. I used one can of beans and one very large sweet potato (probably like the size of 2 normal ones).
I sauteed the onion and garlic with some kale and I added the spices to that. I used oregano, chipotle powder, cayenne, cumin, and turmeric. Once that was the right consistence I added a can of pinto beans. I just added the boiled sweet potato straight into the bean mixture and blended it up using an immersion blender. Those were the main things that I changed and I think the turned out great. The recipe as written 3 stars since it has some weird ingredients and unnecessary steps (Why would you add so much water? Why put the beans and the sweet potato in separately?), 4.5 stars for how it turned out when I made it.
Served with salsa verde, diced onions, cilantro, and plain Greek yogurt instead of sour cream.

I was so mad after trying to make this recipe, that I wasn't even hungry anymore. My kitchen is a total disaster from trying to "mash" beans in a boiling hot pan (which BTW, you will need a very large pan if you make the suggested quantity, not a medium pan). I'm learning how to find the REAL recipes on this site, and this is not one of them.

text:
Just tried this tonight - I love it! I'm a university student and I don't cook all that often, so it took me a while to figure out the sweet potato.. found it was easiest to microwave it for 10-15 minutes and then scoop it out, then you don't have to mash it. I followed the directions pretty much exactly, except I did add a little less water. Also, I added the water while I was mashing the beans, so it got absorbed better and made the mashing easier. I made these with whole-wheat tortillas, so I can actually feel good about what I'm eating instead of fries or KFC every night... Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I made these for a vegetarian friend and had more than I needed to give her, so I hesitantly tried one. I am so glad I did because this is in my top 10 list of favorite foods and we always have some in the freezer for lunches or quick suppers. I don't mash the beans- I just buy 2 cans of refried black beans and then don't add as much water. I wrap them individually in foil and freeze them in a freezer bag. Bake them at 350 for 35-40 min and you're good to go. Thaw them out first, and you just have 15 min. These really are addictive.

text:
Yes, this is "weird" in that it is different from your typical bean burrito-- but I thought it was very good for an easy meal for 2 non-vegetarians trying to eat more vegetarian meals. I thought,  "Really, 3 TBSP chile powder" (not a typo) & "TWO cups of water"??  Well, to solve the "bean soup" problem, and the "bland" sweet potato concerns, I cut the microwave-cooked sweet potatoes into cubes, & mixed it with the bean mix, creating the perfect blend of texture, taste, & water absorption for the burrito filling. I put the filling directly into the flour tortillas with the cheddar cheese, because I was on a hot houseboat, & did not want to turn on the oven. Because I had no potato masher or food processor to mash the kidney beans, it took a while longer to mash with a fork, but not impossible(think camping).  I would gladly make this again, especially if the filling I froze, tastes as good as other reviewers proclaimed.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice, and even though it requires a fair amount of prep work AND is a bit fussy, the end result is well worth it. You taste crunch and sweetness first and you're thinking, okay, that's different, then the spicy bean mixture hits and your mind is officially blown. Caveats that I would offer: 1) Choose the ginormous tortillas meant for burritos, not the smaller ones intended for soft tacos and fajitas. I never paid any attention to what's written on the different bags until this recipe. If you use the soft taco ones, adjust how much you fill them accordingly and -- bonus -- you'll make even more. 2) Eyeball how much water to add to the pan at the end; for me, over a cup was way too much and I ended up with a bean soup. 3) Watch the burrito assembly video tutorial or you'll end up with some funky-looking packages.

text:
I'm not vegetarian but I made these for a vegetarian girlfriend who just had a baby - it's awesome because it A) makes so much B) is filling and good C) will be easy to heat after freezing D) lots of protein for a breastfeeding mom E) it's so easy for an exhausted new mom to eat when she has 30 seconds to spare. The recipe made a TON! I ran out of wheat tortillas (16 taco sized - there's enough for 18 I think) before I ran out of either filling (plan on mixing the extra beans with rice and using the sweet potatoes just as a side to a dinner). I froze them wrapped in paper towels, on a sheet tray then threw them (wrapped) into a Ziplock bag exactly as Toni mentioned. So so pleased with this recipe. UPDATE: I had so much of the bean mixture left over, I froze it for a rainy day. Just made a snack for the hubby who's always starved when he gets home from work - stuffed whole wheat pita halves with 2 spoonfuls of the bean mixture, then a sprinkle of cheddar cheese and froze them. He's so happy!

text:
Made this for dinner last weekend and it turned out lovely. I thought it was kind of a pain to make, what with cooking and mashing the sweet potatoes and mashing the beans and all. They had a nice flavor though, spices were a nice mix with the sweetness of the potatoes. HOWEVER - the recipe states it makes 12 servings?? I halved the recipe and made BIG burritos, and it still made 10!! Another reviewer stated that they freeze well, I hope thats true, because I have 7 of them frozen. Would be a shame to waste all that time if they don't keep well in the freezer. But they were good, and VERY filling! My husband only ate two, and he has a big BIG appetite!
Changes I made:  As suggested by other reviewers, I used black beans instead of kidney beans since i didn't have any kidney beans. 
I added more cumin & chili powder, along with a bit of soul seasoning since it still tasted just a bit bland. But we like lots of spice & flavor around here!
Overall, these were very good, and if they keep well in the freezer, I will be making them again!

So I had some friends over for dinner last night and made these. In case I haven't rated them I must. They are a hit every time. Incredible. Try them. I add about 1.5-2 times the flavorings/seasonings because I like big flavor. I also make one little change in assembly. To avoid big globs of sweet potato I like to smear the sweet potato over the whole tortilla, then the beans in a strip. The beans are right in the middle and the potato looks like pinwheels. Even my guests who don't like sweet potatoes ate an uncomfortable amount of these delectable treats. These are a must try.

country:

text:
I couldn't help but to saute the onion and garlic in 1/2 cup Goya sofrito (freezer section) and 1/4 of a diced Cubanelle pepper, then added 1 can each of drained red and black beans nd 1/2 cup water, roughly mashing the mixture. To 4 baked, mashed sweet potatoes, I added 1/2  tsp. each salt and ground chipotle pepper. Due to unforeseen circumstances I froze both mixtures and thawed them this past weekend (worked GREAT!) For the tortillas, used our favorite Chi-Chi's brand Cafe Style enchilada-size  tortillas (a corn flour and wheat flour tortilla). I prepared 10 Burritos, veggie spraying the seam side, laying the seam side down on a baking sheet, and veggie sprayed the tops. Placed baking sheet in lower 1/3 of the oven and turned burritos 10 minutes into the baking. They were browned/crispy and delicious. My hubby and I gave them 2 thumbs up, adding more spicy condiments as we like to do.  I took leftovers to work this week and throughly enjoyed them!  This deviated from the posted recipe, but I do see that others have made their own versions from this tasty "stepping stone" of a recipe!

This sounds a bit weird, but my husband and I just finished eating these for supper, and any doubts we may have had are gone! Because it's just the two of us eating these, I used two cans of beans (1 can of kidney and 1 can of black beans), and I used two sweet potatoes. I used the same amount of garlic and onion, but for the spices I used 2 Tbs. chili powder, 2 tsp. cumin, 3 tsp. mustard, same amount of cayenne, and 2 Tbs. soy sauce. I also cut the water down to only 1 c. We made four burritos, and have some beans left over. Really, really delicious! What a great combination of flavors!

text:
I made a few changes based on other reviews, my own tastes, and to make it slightly healthier (the calorie count on this is a bit high)...I used evoo to sautee a small onion and 4 cloves of pressed garlic.  Then I added 4 cans of black beans, and about 1 cup water (I just added a little at the time until I got the consistancy I wanted), then I added the other ingredients.  I had baked 4 sweet potatoes (not sure how many cups this was, but it's what I used), and went ahead and mixed the potatoes in with the bean mixture.  Then I spread onto whole wheat tortillas.  I omitted the cheese, and baked as directed.  These were wonderful!  My 7 yr old son loved it, and so did I.  Very filling.  I wrapped the extras in a paper towel, and popped in zip lock bags and put in the freezer for lunches!

text:
This recipe is a new favorite in our house.  One change we did make to make things easier was to 'chop' the beans up in a food processor.  Comments to use a fork, potato mashers, etc, were unsuccessful.  But the food processor makes them more like refried beans and easier to work with.  However, the full recipe makes A LOT of food!  I can't stress that enough!  One burrito itself is so filling, and 12 is too much to bake at one time. We baked 6 and froze the other 6 in a casserole dish.  Following KEANSOR's comment to heat from frozen for 30 in 350 then 15 without foil...ours were frozen solid after half an hour.  We kept them for about 50 minutes under foil in the casserole dish, then with no foil for about another 25-30 minutes.  Perhaps it just depends on the oven, but ours definitely needed more time.

Final product was decent and certainly very very filling. I wish I had mixed the potatos with the bean mixture before putting it into the tortilla, though. I suggest watching the amount of water you mix into the beans, you may not need as much as it calls for, and also you may wish to let the whole mixture simmer as you're adding spices so they can blend and the whole pot wont be as watery in the end.

text:
Wow, these were interesting and definitely a 5 for both taste and originality!  I made a few modifications that might help other users.  I used black beans, as suggested by other users, instead of pinto.  Instead of mashing the bean/garlic/onion mix, I threw it all in a food processor and blended it for a few minutes.  Also, I used only 3/4 of the water recommended (I halved the recipe, so 3/4 cup total).  I used whole wheat tortillas and my halved recipe made 10 burritos!  I cooked all of them and 6 are currently in my freezer, waiting to be microwaved.  I didn't use cheese, but added pico de gallo and sliced avocado for sides.  They were delicious and you should try them!

text:
I decided to make these tonight even though I didn't have any cheese in the house. I used one can of black beans and 2 sweet potatoes. I mashed the sweet potatoes and flavored them with some salt, oil and added a bit of their cooking liquid to help them reach the right consistancy. The beans I did exactly like the recipe except I scaled the ingredients down and I eye-balled the water - I didn't want them to be watery. I spread the beans and sweet potato on the inside of a warmed homemade flatbread/tortilla and then layered chopped onion, tomato and sliced avocado on top. Then finally added salsa and tobasco on the inside. Then I rolled this up and that's it. I didn't bake it, but it was delicious anyway. I loved the combo of the beans and sweet potatoes. I will definitely make this again - next time I'll try them with cheese although it really doesn't need it. My DH commented that the salsa was needed to combat the dryness of the beans and sweet potatoes. Thanks!

country:

text:
i made these exactly as the recipe shows.  They taste like bean burros with sweet potato added, nothing more, nothing less- rather bland, unless you add more cheyenne pepper.   It was a lot of work for something that really should be  quite simple.  Bean burros use pinto beans, you cook them until soft( this does take time), smash them up with a bunch of cheese and salt.  Or you buy a can of refried beans.  I'm more than willing to spend time making a good recipe, and honestly, once you add lettuce, sour cream, salsa , tomatoes and cheese to the top you can have nothing more than a cheese burro and it will taste great.  I ate this without the toppings and with.  Obviously with all the toppings it tasted great, just like a regular bean burro with toppings would have.  Without the toppings it tasted just like a bean burro with sweet potatoes added. I would suggest if you want to have an idea of the taste, just get a can of refried beans, some cheese and cook some sweet potatoes. Put them together and warm through.  My big problem is that this recipe took a lot of time and it really didn't need to.

Love this recipe! I am not typically a fan of any type of canned bean, but this was delicious. Before eating the burritos, I splashed on some hot sauce -- super yummy!

5 for great tasting meat free meal! I loved these! For future use I will remember that the amount of beans has to be equal to or slightly greater than the sweet potato. I made some with a little more sweet potato than bean and didn't really like those...I actually prefer about 2/3 bean to 1/3 pot, but 1/2 1/2 was good too! madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5981238.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are delicious!
To all skeptics out there, give these a whirl as everyone who has sampled mine have loved them.
They are great with the usual Mexican food style garnishes: sour cream,salsas, avocado,etc or by themselves. I also agree with other reviewers that they reheat well in the microwave if refrigerated or from frozen if you want to keep a "pre-made" meal on hand for days when you're short on time.

**Tip: if you really want to save time or just like to be a little lazier on occasion, you can forget about cooking the beans/spices and instead warm up a can of ranch style beans. You get the same flavor, less hassle,  and you don't even need to mash the beans before putting them in the tortillas. This is how I made my last batch and everyone loved them just as much.

I thought this tasted pretty good. It seemed like the taste got better as it cooled. I liked how the sweet potato, was more added for color or nutrition, as it couldn't really be tasted. I also used Goya pinto beans, because that is what I had.

text:
No wonder this recipe has over 1,000 reviews with over 50,000 saving it.  IT'S AMAZING! (Read "BlackEye"'s suggestions on 17 Dec. '10 for GREAT tips).  I made this using homemade black beans (soak overnight, rinse, boil with onion, garlic, parsley, & 2 bay leaves.  Rinse; discard parsley and bay leaves and food-process the rest with vegetable broth to your consistency).  I also slow cooked the sweet potatoes as I think adding water to cook them would leach the rich taste out of them.  I also "veganized" it by using "Daiya" cheese (the ONLY vegan cheese I use) and making my own tortilla wraps.  It's delicious with shredded lettuce and pineapple salsa over it, although next time I think I'll use regular salsa over it because I'd like to give it more "oomph" spice-wise.  Very filling.  EXCELLENT recipe.

text:
these are simple, but amazingly yummy! if you can just imagine the flavors, then this is definitely your recipe. i am doing a cleanse this week where i can not eat meat & this is satisfying! i halved the recipe & got 11 burritos using 'fajita' sized tortillas. i also didn't have much cheese, so only 2 made it. they taste good with or with out. i used 1 can of red kidney beans, 1 can of white kidney beans. i started slowly adding the water by the 1/2 cup after reading it was too much. i used less than a cup, but add up to your desired consistency. i also added more cayenne since i love spicy food & i am the only one eating these. the only other thing that would've made them better is if i had some pico de gallo & guacamole. i ate 2 for dinner, packed 2 for lunch & froze the rest for this week. i am anxious to try them later as some food taste better the next day after marinating in their flavor.

text:
I had it calculate 4 servings and it was the perfect amount for 4 large tortillas.  Excellent spice and taste!!  I am now a believer too.  I used black beans & a potato masher.  I used canned sweet potatoes. I only used 1 TBS of water based on other reviews, but I think it could have used a TBS more. I would wait to throw spices onto the onions till they are sauted because the spices make it hard to tell when the onions are done. Don't forget to turn the burritos mid-way through cooking to leave a nice brown surface.  I served with a topping of sour cream & salsa with side of rice.

text:
Interested in this immediately..Did mostly follow the recipe but used re-fried black beans AND Red kidney beans which I mashed and combined.  I suppose one could buy pre - mashed sweet potatoes but i chose the organic route and bought, peeled, boiled, and mashed. Added diced bell pepper to onion in skillet.  Incorporated a 1/2 cup mozzarella cheese to bean mixture. Topped mix with 4 cheese Mexican shredded cheese prior to folding burrito.  Being it is a savory AND sweet dish combination, I beautified it by adding a spoonful of mango salsa on top finished off with a lovely fresh basil leaf. Offered sour cream on the side as well as salsa verde and/or hot sauce....YUMMY!!

text:
These were absolutely wonderful! I did change the recipe a bit, but even my husband (who is not into spicy food) loved them. I used black beans instead of kidney beans (I rinse them to get rid of extra salt). My husband's had cheese while mine had jalapenos. I would think adding black olives to this would taste great. I also added a little fresh mango when I pureed the yams (I couldn't buy sweet potatoes, worked out well anyway) and that was very nice. I think next time I would also bring down the amount of chili powder by just a smidge. Wonderful recipe for vegetarians and very easily made vegan.

text:
Mmm, delicious!  Of course I modified the recipe a bit for my own tastes and they were superb!  I used canned black beans instead of kidney & I did put them in the food processor first.  For those that said there was something missing...I threw in a chopped jalapeño pepper to the bean mixture and pureed it along with the beans.

I too didn't use all the water called for and I also mixed the bean and potato mixture up together before making the burritos.  I made these into 8 huge burritos and put them in a 11x13" casserole dish and covered them in enchilada sauce and a nice layer of cheese.  I chopped up some fresh cilantro just before they were finished and sprinkled it on top.  

Even my picky kids gobbled them up and wanted more!  I'll definitely make these again!

text:
Delicious!  Following the suggestions of an earlier reviewer, I use black beans instead of kidney beans and vegetable broth instead of water, and I saute the spices with the onions and garlic to bring out the flavor.  I prefer corn tortillas to flour, so I make these as quesadillas instead of burritos.  To do this, I spoon on some sweet potato then some bean mixture, covering half the tortilla, sprinkle on a little low-fat shredded cheddar, and fold the tortilla over. (To keep the tortillas from ripping when I fold them, I heat them a little on each side in a non-stick skillet before adding the filling.) Then, I heat the quesadillas in the skillet on each side until brown and crisp and serve with some salsa on top.

text:
Wow... this was delicious!  The whole time I was cooking, I was thinking, "I don't know about this..." but it came out really, really good.  As other reviewers suggested, I browned the onions for a couple of minutes and then I added the garlic and spices for a couple of minutes.  I added the beans and mashed them a bit - not competely.  Just opened them up some. Then I added 1/2 the water.  I let it simmer for about 10 minutes.  Then I turned off the heat and added the mashed sweet potatoes (which I added syrup to) right to the beans.  I sprinkled the cheese on top, mixed it all together, and then filled the burritos.  Delicious!  Thanks for the surprisingly good recipe! ADDITIONAL NOTE:  I make these all the time now.  I always add the spices to the onions and garlic and let them saute for a minute or 2 before I add the beans and water.  I forgot to do that last night, for some reason, and I followed the recipe as written.  That is, I added the spices AFTER I added the water.  HUGE, HUGE difference.  The spices were kind of dormant.  They weren't really there.  I won't make that mistake again!

text:
These were very good. The beans were delicious--very similar to refried beans but with more flavor. I didn't use all the water called for--I just used enough to get it to a pasty texture. I used a small amount of cheddar-style goat cheese, but I think these would be great without, as well. I also used sprouted-grain tortillas, which got nice and crispy (but not hard) after baking. The beauty of this recipe is that it's open to variation--next time, I'll add green chilies and guacamole.

These were wonderful - my whole family loved them!  I was very skeptical, because I thought the combination of ingredients sounded weird.  They had the most delicious, unique flavor.  I used two cans of black beans and one large can of refried beans in place of the kidney beans.  I omitted the cayenne pepper and used more chili powder and cumin than called for.  I decreased the mustard to 2 teaspoons, and mixed the sweet potatoes with the bean mixture before rolling in the tortillas and baking.  Well worth the time and effort!!  Thank you so much for this very different and fabulous recipe!

text:
I thought these were pretty good, and have a lot of potential.  I halved the recipe and used black beans instead of kidney beans (taste preference).  I also used less water with the beans.  I found that I put too much of the sweet potato mixture on the tortillas and it was too overpowering.  Next time I would mix the potato and bean mixture together before applying to tortillas, probably in the food processor.  I also forgot to put cheese inside tortillas, so placed on top before baking, would likely have been better with the cheese directly inside.  I poured a little bit of milk over top prior to baking to add some creaminess.  Very good with sour cream.

text:
I discovered this recipe years ago and have been making these ever since! My only variation (which is tastier and easier in my opinion) is this:  I use refried black beans instead of the whole kidney beans. More flavorful, better texture, and much easier than mashing whole beans. Just use about 1/2 cup to whole cup less than the recipe calls for and less water.  I also find that Colby Jack cheese is a nice replacement for cheddar, as it melts so nicely and pairs well with the other flavors. Less oily, too. Sour cream on top is definitely delish!

1) a mixture of 2 types of beans,(red kidney and black for me) 
2) something about baking them makes them so much better. get a little char going. come to think of it possibly good on the grill. topped with sour cream and salsa its like a vegetarian burrito that tastes like beans and beef but better. 
3)I added more cheese per unit. nothing wrong with being healthy but we do need some calories to burn 

future experiment: needs a little more contrast in the texture. wanna say cauliflower but dont know why .. hmmm

Delicious flavors! I can't resist tweaking recipes so here is what I did.... Added dry spices to onions and sautéed for one minute to intensify flavor. Roasted poblano peppers and layered between sweet potato and beans. Used gluten free tortillas and flipped halfway through baking to get both sides crisp. Served with purple cabbage and carrot slaw. Can't wait to try the leftovers stashed in the freezer!

text:
Surprisingly awesome!  Half the recipe.  This makes a ton.  I halved it and made 13 fajita wrap-sized burritos.... 2-3 each per person and we were satisfied.  Follow the other recommendations: use black beans, a potato masher to half smash the beans when they're in the pan cooking with the onion, and less water.  We actually used about 1/2 cup and tried broth for some added flavor.  This is a wonderful healthy and satisfying meal.  Perfect combo of salty, sweet, and savory!

text:
These were addictive. I had to have two! My wife loved them also, and our picky two year old who only wants sugar filled food all the time enjoyed them. I took the advice of other reviewers and combined the sweet potato and red bean mash. That was easier and it tasted fantastic. I loaded them up with double the cheese and put olive oil on the outside of the tortillas before baking. The sweet potato I boiled, drained and mashed into the beans. I subsequently added no water to the mix. Served with guacamole, newman's own peach salsa, and sour cream spooned on top. yum! I have enough leftovers for the week too!!

userID:
8764812
Display Name:
Ilene Kramer
isPro:

19
favoritesCount:
681

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2434549.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, despite its simplicity, is a lot of work. So it's not for the faint of heart!  It's truly worth all the effort though for two reasons. 1 - it's delicious! and 2 - it makes enough to save for the week ahead. I'm not sure why anyone had trouble mashing the beans as you warm them; I didn't find it much of an effort. I did, however, add chicken to each burrito (some baked chicken tenders which were easy to shred). The result was excellent. I ran into a bit of trouble, though, because I was unable to portion out the sweet potatoes evenly, so the last burrito had a double portion of beans in it. I also had some leftover beans that I saved in a plastic bag that I will use as a side dish some other night.
Karena - Thank you for this recipe!!

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe though I did make numerous changes. The most important one is I used BUTTERNUT SQUASH instead of sweet potatoes!!  I cooked and mashed it just like a sweet potato. I am on a diet that uses Points and with the squash I don't need to count those starchy vegetable points. I also substituted curry powder for the cumin, added 4 tsp. of taco seasoning, used honey mustard, and used high fiber no fat tortilla wraps. Also I used chicken broth in place of water and mashed my kidney beans ahead with a potato masher. I also cooked the filling all together, not separate, and simmered for 15 minutes. I'll definitely make these again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were great! I used kidney beans as recommended. I prepped the sweet potatoes by baking them in a 450 deg. oven for an hour, then peeling the skins off and mashing. 

I did make a few changes-I sautéed the onion and garlic with the spices first as another reviewer suggested, used dijon mustard, and replaced the soy sauce/cayenne with salt and pepper. I found that it did not need the 2c water. 

When baking the burritos, I lined the sheet with parchment paper and flipped them halfway through to get both sides crispy.

This definitely made enough for 12 burritos made out of 8" tortillas. I ate it with plain greek yogurt, diced fresh tomatoes, and lettuce on top!

text:
As one reviewer said, this was better than I thought it would be. I was looking for something different to do with 1 sweet potato and what I had in the pantry. My proportions were 1 can of black beans, don't like kidney, to the 1 sweet potato and everything else was just to taste. Mashed the beans and added the potatoes to the beans before putting them in the skillet. Cooked the spices with the onion & garlic. I also used brown mustard instead of yellow. The amount gave me enough for 3 large burritos. I also used canned jalapeno (embasa brand) instead of cayenne. Interesting burrito, it did taste good but I'm not sure I will make this again. Don't know, it might grow on me.

userID:

Display Name:
Tami Baity

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/516039.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, as is, I give 4 stars. The water in this recipe makes the filling way to runny. Black beans are much tastier than kidney. I baked the sweet potatoes cut in half on a cookie sheet for an hour in a 400 degree oven. When they cooled, I scooped out the flesh and added them to the black beans I had mashed in the4 bowl. I added all the spices, mustard (I used dry and half the amount) and low sodium soy sauce into the potatoes and beans. I sauteed the onion and garlic in a small pan and added them to the mixture. Before folding them up, I grated just about 1oz of jalapeno jack cheese before folding them up. Definitely don not skip putting them in the oven! They come out warm and crispy. We loved these! My husband ate 4 of them!!

These were interesting.  Very different.  Different, but good.  My 8-year old made a funny face with her first bite and I assumed she didn't like it.  She said, "It's weird.  It tastes good, but weird."  That about sums it up.  They are very good, but very different.  Definitely a keeper.  Next time I will add less water.  I had to use a strainer to drain off some of the liquid in the bean mixture - too soupy.  I also reduced the amount of the chili powder and cumin because I was afraid it would be too much for my kids.  Next time, I'll use the full amount.  Oh - I also completely forgot to put the cheese in and they were still good!

country:

text:
I'm still a little mixed as to whether or not this was really great or just good.  I followed other's advice and used black beans, and mashed them together with the potatoes, as I couldn't see a point in mashing separately.  While this did make a kind of gross-colored mash, I'm not one to care much about the color of my food unless I'm serving company, so it was no big deal.  I halved the recipe but found this lacking just a bit in flavor, so I wish I'd left the spices at full measure.  All in all, I was "wow this is great!" with one bite, and "hmm.. it's good, but not phenomenal" with the next, so never could make up my mind.  I think the sour cream and salsa really added that lacking flavor, I don't know that I would have cared for it a lot without the extra condiments.  Still, I'm looking forward to leftovers and I would probably make this again and play around with the spices a little more.

text:
These were good! I couldn't imagine how it would taste but thought since it got such good reviews I'd give it a go and I'm glad I did. I only gave it 4 stars because I made changes.

Didn't use cheese, and really didn't miss (and I LOVE cheese). Use dried black beans. Made a much smaller batch, and it still made tons. Added salsa, greek yogurt, tomatoes, jalepenos and green onions on top. When I cooked the beans I just added seasoning to taste, but left out the soy sauce and cayenne. Added cilantro paste from a jar for the saltiness.

Will definitely make again!

text:
My husband and I decided to eat vegetarian for a week or so, and these burritos were Meal #1.  We both really liked these, although they are not your typical mexican burritos.  First, I scaled the recipe way down for just the 2 of us (One can of beans, Two small sweet potatoes, 4 tortillas, etc.)  I used white kidney beans instead of black beans.  I also mashed the sweet potatoes prior to adding to the skillet, which I think is the easiest way to go.  Even though I went heavy with the cayenne and chili powder, next time I might add jalapenos or green chilies to the mixture for added heat.  Or maybe just use monterery jack pepper cheese.  These are easy to make so next time, I'll make more to put away in the freezer.  These are quite hearty too!  (One filled me, two filled him.)  Thanks for a fantastic, "addictive" recipe, Karena.  Oh, BTW:  He just said 4.5 star!!!

I made vegan versions of these burritos tonight. A few of my friends stopped by and all agreed they were delicious. I read a few reviews and followed various pieces of advice. One was that I added the spices to the onions as I cooked them. I also added some corn, and used black beans in place of kidney beans. Mashing the blackbeans in the can made it easier. I added a few tablespoons of nutritional yeast flakes, and a little extra soy sauce and mustard. I served them with salsa and froze the rest for later! Really good, filling, and easy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe to the letter. I was skeptical, and for good reason. The seasonings are very overpowering. The sweet potatoe gives a subtle sweet taste and the beans (mashed in food processor) give it great flavor however, the chili powder and cumin are too much. It does not blend well. We added sour cream and that helped slightly. I will not be making these again, but if I did, I would use at least half the amount of spices. The upside is this is a great recipe for vegetarians, with slight modifications.

text:
A new family staple.  My husband wishes I'd make this every week.  They freeze well if you wrap each in foil and then can be taken for lunch at work and reheated in the microwave.  The only change I've made after making this many times is that I substitute fat free refried beans for the kidney beans and use one can of black beans (unmashed).  It just saves so much time since I don't have a large food processor any more and I really can't tell any difference in the taste and I'm all about the easy time saving shortcuts.  Try this one. . . you won't be sorry!

userID:
4580572
Display Name:
GuitarGray
isPro:

1
favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe has become a staple in my home.  We are budget conscious, health conscious, and ecologically conscious. This fits well with all of those needs, and is very tasty!  We usually make a double batch,wrap in aluminum foil, and freeze most of them, so we can grab one any time we are hungry or toss one in the lunch sack. They take being frozen very well, almost no loss in flavor.  A few changes we make:  1) Homemade tortillas. They taste better and (for those of you that care) don't have a bunch of dough conditioners and preservatives. They are easy to make, flour and shortening.   2) Dried beans, not canned. They take longer to make, but we use them because they are less expensive, keep longer, and don't have as much salt. Plus, we can buy organically.   All in all, even when limiting produce choices to organic options, a double batch of these things costs us about $30. The ingredients are all very cheap. At 24 servings we usually end up with about 18 burritos, for $30.   They are nutritious, cheap, easy to make, and taste great. A winner!

text:
I was hesitant to make these b/c the recipe calls for an interesting blend of ingredients (soy sauce and yellow mustard in a burrito??).  however, I am glad I tried it.  The bean mixture is actually VERY good.  I think I went a little heavy on the sweet potato b/c mine turned out a tad too sweet to be GREAT but they are good, especially when topped with salsa and sour cream.  I just made mine and haven't frozen or reheated any yet so I can't comment on that but if they are as easy to freeze and reheat as the other reviewers say, this is a terribly EASY make ahead meal for those times you are short on time.  I think I will try this recipe again sometime only I will go a bit easier on the sweet potatoes and heavier on the bean mixture (I had a LOT of the bean mixture left over so I'm sure I didn't use enough in the burritos.  I'll most likely top the burritos with the extra when I reheat them tomorrow.) If I could,I would have given this a 3.5 star rating b/c it is better than average but unfortunately that is not an option and I have to err on the side of 3 due to the slight over sweetness.

text:
Spectacular!  Although I do admit to changing the recipe a little to suit what I had on hand.  I used curry powder instead of cumin, and used one 19oz can of kidney beans and one 19 oz can of black beans.  The sweet potato was huge, so I might have used more than the 4 cups.  I also liked the idea of corn as used in one of the reviews, so added some of that.  Mashed the sweet potatos in a pot, added the beans.  Fried the onions, garlic & spices in another pan, then added the bean/potato mixture to the pan to combine.  Great stuff - I'm looking forward to freezing the leftovers and having them for lunch.  I'll make this again with different variations and will try to follow the actual recipe as well, just to compare.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DEFINITELY mix the beans and sweet potatoes together. It makes all the difference. Also, Please add some salt. The recipe doesn't call for any.  I added 1/2 teaspoon and it was perfect.  Without it, it was perfectly bland, for all the people who said it was missing something that they couldn't put their finger on, it was SALT, it brings out all the other flavors. Start with a 1/4 tsp, add more to your liking. I fried these up in a skillet and served with sour cream, cilantro, salsa.  With these changes it goes from a 4 star recipe to a 5 star.

None
text:
We had these last night and they were good, but I added a couple of things to "kick it up a notch". As written, I would give it a 3.5 because I think it's a little bland. I added three chopped jalapenos to the onion and garlic mixture which helped. I substituted black beans for the kidney; and the sour cream added at serving is a must! I baked mine for health reasons and the tortillas were a little tough (they were whole wheat too which could contribute)but I'm sure deep frying would make them crispier. I baked my potatoes the night before and peeled and mashed when ready to assemble; I also mashed the beans in a bowl before adding them to the skillet, both which helped make it less difficult. I will try them again; all in all a nice, healthy meat-free meal.

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2008-05-23T05:16:51.96
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
342976
Display Name:
somethingdifferentagain?!
isPro:
False
followersCount:
138
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
383
favoritesCount:
4914
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/170591.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed the recipe exactly. The amount of water sounded like too much to me. I wish I would have gone with my instincts, and added only half (or even less)it was so liquidy that I boiled down some, and then added the sweet potatoes to thicken it up. I actually preferred the TASTE better, mixed up. I used 1/3 cup mix to each 10" burrito and it made 24! I think more filling would have been too much for our preferences, but maybe my tortillas were smaller than other burrito tortillas? They had a terrific flavor and I will make again. But, I would prefer adding at least some black beans, like others have used. Oh... and for those of you (like me) that have never cooked sweet potatoes before... (thanks to "bellydancer" for the info) wrap individually in foil and bake @375 for about 45 minutes for med- large ones and PUT A PAN UNDERNEATH BECAUSE THEY LEAK A SWEET STICKY JUICE (makes sense..."sweet" potatoes) THAT IS A REAL MESS TO CLEAN OFF YOUR OVEN.

My review isn't really a reflection of the actual recipe but I think this recipe allows for the ideas to flow!

text:
This recipe is 5 stars...with a couple additions.  I pretty much followed the amounts of all ingredients, but did halve the amount of water.  Don't be afraid of the soy and mustard, it gives it an unusual taste, and one that goes great with the sweet potato.  I also added a little syrup to the potatoes as others suggested.  But what I think made this recipe 5 stars was adding sauteed onions and peppers (with some garlic salt, garlic powder and fajita seasoning, and serving it with avocado, sour cream and salsa.  I think the cheese and sour cream can be optional as long as you have avocado though.  I also chopped up some tomatoes but they didn't really need that.  Next time I think I will put the peppers and onions right in the burrito, and maybe just use a bigger tortilla.  Anyways, great recipe, my boyfriend and I both loved it-thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/30653.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tasty and healthy. The burritos were liked by all who ate them. In addition to the sweet potatoes and beans, I cooked brown rice and added a couple of tablespoons for some added texture. I agree with some reviewers that the sweet potatoes seem a bit bland. The recipe doesn't specify how to get "mashed sweet potatoes" so the first time I boiled them, mashed them, and used them plain. The second time I baked them, scooped out the flesh, mixed it with a little milk, lime juice, cumin, and fresh cilantro- a better result in my opinion.  Served with pico de gallo and guacamole. Best of all, 12 burritos was too many, so I put the extra, unbaked ones in the freezer. Cook them in the microwave for a minute or two and then bake as usual and they taste just as good as  the freshly made.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/148338.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i scaled these down to 4 servings; i also omitted the onion since i can't eat the darn things. i was soooo interested in how these came out, since this particular recipe seems so contraversial! so let me add to some of the caution -- the flavor here really is unique, a very odd balance between the sweet potato and the mustard/soy sauce/bean mix. mostly i think that if the mustard was scaled back even more, as well as the soy sauce, the flavors might work a bit better together, as they'd be more subtle. i personally liked it, but i know there's no way my family would. i also added very little water, as suggested, and i more smooshed than mashed to give it a good chunky consistency and maintain distinctness of the flavors. if you want something unusual, you should at least try these. like i said, i liked them, but i'll never make them again -- mostly because the family wouldn't approve of the flavor, and because it's just too much work for something i'll probably never crave. still, ingenuity counts for something - so 4 stars feels right.

country:
None
text:
Very good recipe. Even my husband, who isn't a big fan of sweet potatoes, went for seconds.  I read the comments before making and decided to go with black beans.  I'm glad I did.  The beans alone are something I would make again, for various mexican dishes. Much better than refried beans. 
I didn't add any water at all to the bean mixture. The brand I bought had a thicker liquid that didn't drain completely. What little was left in the can was all I thought it needed in the pot, even one cup of water would have made it too soupy.  So, keep that in mind when cooking.  Add a little bit of water at a time and see how it goes from there.

Very yummy recipe!  The only addition I would make is to chop up a chipotle pepper or two (the kind canned in adobo sauce) and add to the sweet potato mixture prior to assembly.  Adds a nice kick! text:
I wasn't totally smitten with this recipe, but my boyfriend loved it, so it gets a four star average.  I normally love cumin, but it just didn't work for me in this.  I will attempt to make this again, but will cut back the cumin and omit mustard (I hate mustard) and add a little cinnamon and nutmeg to complement the sweetness of the potatoes a little more because that was the prominent flavor.  I also thought that one small onion was too much for me, so I’ll cut way back on that as well.  I mashed the beans and potatoes together and I loved that flavor before I added most of the spices.  I also added some sautéed spinach to the mixture.  I think that this recipe will stay in my menu rotation, but I will make some changes until it suits my tastes.  It’s a great idea though.  Sweet potatoes are one of the ‘wonder foods’, so I’m always looking for new and interesting ways to incorporate them in my diet.

None
text:
This is one of my families all time favorite recipes.  It is a little time consuming so if I need to speed things up a little, I use refried beans instead of the kidney beans.  Depending on what I have on hand, I often use half kidney, half refried.  I also add taco seasoning to the bean mixture.  Add hot seasoning if you like it spicy, (we don't) this recipe is not spicy at all.  I serve with chopped tomatoes and light sour cream.  To make it a little healthier, I use low fat cheese (mexican style), and whole wheat tortillas.  I also never substitute yams as I only like sweet potatoes.  (There is a difference)  My kids love this recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/162.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I've made these and this time I made some changes to the original recipe to gear it more toward my liking. First - I halved the recipe as the recipe makes alot of filling. I used black beans instead of the kidney beans because I prefer the taste. (The skin is not as tough and mixes better).  I mashed the beans by hand (I like the earthy texture).  And like other reviewer, I didn't add the entire amount of water.
To the sweet potatos, I added 1 TBl soy sauce, some cayenne pepper and 1/2 tsp curry powder.  Instead of the cheddar, which seemed too grainy for the mix, I topped with swiss cheese instead and melted.  I also used sour cream last time and this time added plain yogurt and some fresh chopped cilantro to the burrito.  I hope you enjoy it...this is a keeper for me.

Love, love, love this recipe. We've made these at least a dozen times  over the years and they're a hit every time. While always delicious, these burritos are in a league of their own if you can get your hands on some really good sweet potatoes. Its hit or miss for us at the grocery store.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were quite good. I really liked, and almost loved them. With just a little bit of work it would be 5 stars. First of all based on reviews I decided to go with black beans rather than kidney beans. I also cheated and bought low fat refried black beans so I didn't have to mash them. Because of this I didn't add the water to the mix and I'm glad I didn't. Due to the advice of other reviewers I added the chile powder, cayenne and cumin to the onions and garlic to let them heat up. I also am not a mustard person, so the only one I had was dijon mustard. It was perhaps not the best choice, it made for a very odd smelling mixture but once everything was put together it was fine. I did have a bit more than the required sweet potatoes, but since I love those that wasn't an issue. I would totally make these again! I'll just be more careful with the mustard and I use a lot of cayenne because I love it. I served it with some guacamole and I plan to freeze leftovers.

I make these all the time! As a career woman in my mid-twenties, it's super-easy just to eat out all the time. I make a double batch and keep them in my freezer. Display Name:
Anne In NC
isPro:

11

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were fantastic! Two things a cook must be aware of though... First, unless you want a really mushy burrito, omit the 2 cups of water. I made the recipe with no additional water and it turned out perfectly. Second, they improve with age. The first one that came fresh out of the oven was unimpressive and I wondered why I went through so much trouble. But the second one, re-heated after sitting in the fridge for 12 hours, was amazing! I made half the recipe and had plenty leftover to freeze, and the other reviewers are right, they freeze very well. I plan on making this recipe again. Frequently.

Edit: I made the entire recipe and it got me 19 large burritos. I'm not sure how the author of the recipe managed to fit that much filling into 12 burritos.  Still delicious, just be aware this is a huge recipe and you'll probably need extra tortillas.

text:
Really good! I  did what another reviewer did and just mixed the beans in with the sweet potato mixture. That way, for me, there's only one container to deal with. I also added the spices to the onion when it was almost done sauteeing and let it cook for about a minute, to bring out the flavors of the spices. I also subbed chicken broth for the water and black beans for the kidney (seems more Mexican). I look forward to making it a meal with the fixings as I only sampled out of the pot (couldn't wait). Thanks for the nice recipe, Karena!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Husband and I are doing the 10 day DANIEL diet and was led to this recipe as a suggestion for a meal using WHOLE GRAIN TORTILLAS and no cheese for the sake of the diet. First seeing the strange sweet potatoes with beans concoction made me nervous that this would be one of those 'just tolerate each bite' meals. Especially without cheese! But I was shocked that each bite was quite enjoyable so long as it contained equal amounts of both the sweet potatoes and bean mix. And then I wondered what some spring mix lettuce and tomato would do and threw some on my second burrito. OMG, it was FABULOUS! Wish I'd have thought of it from the start. They were so perfect as is that there was zero longing for cheese or even meat! Like I said, I'm shocked. These will be on our regular menu from now on!

text:
These were surprisingly outstanding. My husband was fasting from sugar and meat while I found this. He lived off these, happily. I was very hesitant about the ingredients working together. I would have never thought to put them together, but they are very happy together. I only had one can of kidney beans and one garbanzo. I blended the chick peas before I added them to the mashed kidneys and it turned out wonderful. We can't normally can't eat burritos or quesadillas without sour cream and salsa but there was no need for anything extra. I made a bunch of them at once and wrapped them in plastic, then aluminum so he could grab 'n go. These were great and I'm making them again tonight.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are really great.  I did follow the suggestions by Black Eye and omitted the water and added shriracha and sweet chili sauces--excellent.  (I did use drained, canned black beans for expedience...)  Also, I don't heat them in the regular oven.  Don't want to dry them out, So I just wrap what I'm serving right away in damp paper towels and microwave for 1-2 minutes, add a dollop of plain Greek yogurt topped with a bit of salsa fresca and--yum!  Since there's just the two of us, I take the rest (don't bother heating), wrap each one in a fold over sandwich bag and put them all in a gallon size freezer bag. These freeze and heat up beautifully in the microwave.

After I started, I realized I didn't have chili powder, so I used taco seasoning instead. I also used frozen mashed sweet potatoes from Trader Joe's. These are a great! They are a little soggy when you skip the baking step, so if you freeze them like I do, grill them first and then freeze to reheat in the microwave. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had extra fillings left over. I'm glad I cooked some beans this week for several different recipes (yeah me for planning ahead). At the farmer's market I bought sweet potatoes but wasn't sure what I would do with them. I cubed and froze them. So this morning I cooked the sweet potatoes (used some water & used that water residue in the recipe for added vitamins. I went light on the cayanne. This is so mild I could feed it to my toddler. BUT has enough flavor that I"m very happy to recommend this recipe to others. *as the beans were finishing up, I did squeeze half a lime on them as beans*. Other than that the only other change was I added broth and sweet potatoe water instead of plain water. Since I am freezing these I took someone's advice and added cheese on the inside and did not bake these. Wrapped in foil for baking in the future. Cooking the beans yourself from dried and this is not an expensive meal at all and yielded more than 12 burritos.

text:
These were delicious!  I scaled down the recipe to only make 4 burritos and wish I had made more.  The changes I made were not using chili powder and using a big tablespoon of cayenne pepper and oregano, omitting the soy sauce and mustard, and using 1 can kidney beans and 1 can pinto beans (I had leftover beans).  They were spicy and delicious.  Even my husband enjoyed them.  Next time I'll make a full batch and freeze the leftovers.  We served them with sliced tomatoes, cilantro, and sour cream.

These really are addictive! They have a little spicy kick, but not too overwhelming. This recipe made a huge batch, so I wrapped several in foil and froze them. For an easy lunch, I defrosted in the fridge overnight, wrapped in a paper towel, and microwaved on 1/2 power for 2 minutes. An easy, satisfying, on-the-go lunch!

text:
These were pretty tasty! I was worried they were going to taste like straight sweet potatoes, but the flavor was actually quite balanced. I used half kidney beans and half black beans, and added some extra cumin. Mashing the beans is not fun, but the texture is much better when you do. I think I will freeze a couple for those nights when dinner-time sneaks up on you; they should heat up very nicely.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Surprisingly, these are a hit even with people who hate sweet potatoes! We've made these for years, after finding the recipe on a listserve. We do change a few things though - We simmer the beans for another hour because it makes it easier to mash, and add more cayenne powder to spice things up a bit. We also cook the onions down more, so they are clear but soft (I dislike the crunch of raw onions!) 

When we make these, we tend to double or triple the batch, and freeze what we are not eating that evening after cooking. Lunches are as easy as thawing in the fridge overnight, and maybe a few seconds in the microwave at work. 

The copy I have does not include soy sauce, will add some the next time we make these!

text:
This burrito recipe really suprised me. Who knew sweet potatoes could taste like anything but the  marshmallowy, brown-sugary goodness they are known and loved for? I used 1 Cup of water instead of 2, 2 Tbls of low-sodium soy sauce instead of 3 Tbls of the regular, and medium whole wheat tortillas. The filling was enough to fill all of the tortillas in the bag with some left over. I now have 10 burritos ready to take for lunch in my freezer. I used black beans which I mashed before adding to the potato mixture. My Mr. scowled at the concoction I was stirring up until he taste-tested the filling. He too is now a fan!

text:
Pretty darn good! The sweet, savory, and spicy flavors all play off of each other very nicely. I used about twice the cheese the recipe called for, and I'm going to add some more cayenne and maybe some hot sauce next time. I boiled and mashed fresh sweet potatoes and added a little salt. Might add some more spices next time too.

Some of the proportions were a bit off for me; I used half the water called for in the beans and still had more than enough filling, so I made two extra burritos. 

Overall, tasty and unique but a bit time consuming to make.

Fantastic! Combined this recipe w/ the Moosewood Restaurant version. Kept the sweet potato mixture separate from the black bean mixture (didn't blend together) and had no problems mashing the black beans in the skillet with a potato masher. Had more than enough filling for 10 pk of 8" tortillas - the extra filling AND the burritos freeze well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
One of my family's favorites.  Like the others have said, black beans are tastier than kidney beans in this one, and it helps to pre-mash them.  I usually drain the beans and put them in a microwave safe bowl, microwave them for about 60 seconds, and then mash them with a fork.  I'm not a big fan of mustard, but it adds a nice flavor to the recipe.  It's great for my vegetarian friends, and you can also make it vegan if you omit the cheese and check the ingredients on the soy sauce.  They freeze pretty well, too.

text:
YUMMY! Quick and easy to make. I varied it a little and blended the sweet potato and bean mixture together in my stand mixer, as I couldn't find my potato masher anywhere. 
I sprayed a little cooking spray on the tortillas and baked at 425 for 8 minutes, flipped and cooked for 4 more and they turned out crisp and brown. 

The left overs heated up well the next day.

I didn't have enough tortilla shells, so I froze the rest of it. I will update after I thaw it and try to use it again.

This was great. I love cooking with cumin and this recipe caught my eye right away. I upped the spices a bit and didn't have kidney beans but I had cannellini on hand so I used those. They worked perfectly. I did mash the beans before adding to the pan. The burritos were great but I didn't have enough tortillas, so I used some tostada shells: warmed the potatoes and cheese on there first, then added the beans. I also added cilantro on top of mine. So good!

userID:
2583716
Display Name:
AngelicDagger
isPro:

followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
55

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We do not eat beans so we edited it quite a bit.
 
 Start by cooking rice, letting it cool. Saute the onions and garlic then add the rice to make it like fried rice. Cook 1 can of corn, drain completely and place in large bowl. Add the chili powder, cumin, soy sauce, mustard and used a good amount of cayenne pepper. Mix completely. After the rice mixture is cooked, let it cool a bit and add to the corn. 

 Then I boiled some chicken while the sweet potatoes are boiling in another pot. I always make my sweet potatoes with a few tablespoons of butter and some maple syrup. When the chicken is done it's  shredded up then mixed in the rice mixture.

 Put the sweet potatoes on the tortilla first then the rice mixture, top it with cheese if you really want but i've had people love it with out.

text:
If I could give this more stars, I would! This was such a unique blend of ingredients and the flavors were excellent! I did use black beans instead. I would recommend mashing the beans before mixing them with the other ingredients and don't add all the water at once, just keep adding until it forms the right constancy. These don't take long to wrap up at all, so I would add the beans and potato separately as the recipe suggest. They don't need to be mixed together, I think it would mess with the great flavors they both produce when they are divided.  I served it with some sour cream. I can't wait to have these again. They live up to their name!

text:
In a word, Delicious.  I listened to some of the other comments and decided to use a mixture of 2/3 refried beans and 1/3 black beans instead of the kidney beans.  I also used half the amount of water when making the bean mixture.  Lastly, I doubled the amount of cheese and used a mixture of 1/2 pepper-jack and 1/2 cheddar.  They came out delicious.  In the future I'll also add in more spices to give them an extra kick.

text:
These got a bit of a lukewarm reception at our house.  Bf said they were "weird" which I sometimes think is his euphemism for "don't like".  He still ate them, though, and these are incredibly filling--usually he'd eat two burritos (at least) in one sitting but he only managed one tonight.  He also muttered about the lack of cheese--which I did put in--but I guess he wanted more.  I like this combo, and I think I'll end up eating the leftovers.  I did freeze about 8 of them--the rest I'll eat for lunches during the week.  I ended up with less sweet potato than the kidney bean filling, so I had about 4 burritos without the sweet potato.  I guess those are bfs!  I tossed in more cayenne than I intended, but it really didn't make them too spicy, for which I'm grateful, as we aren't huge spicy food fans.  All in all, I guess bf isnt' thrilled by the sweet potato, so if I make again I'd have to cut down or leave out the sweet potato (yes, I know, that makes this recipe not live up to it's title!) and add more cheese for the bf.  I do like the method of baking to crisp up, although I broiled for a couple of minutes as well to brown.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Finally tried out this recipe last night.  They were really nice and I will definitely make again. I used two cans of black beans and one can of kidney beans. I found it easy to mash the beans right in the pan (I noticed other reviewers saying they mashed before due to difficulties).  I also added the mashed potatoes to the bean mixture before putting into tortillas.  The recipe makes a large batch and I could not get all the mixture into the Old El Paso tortillas I had.  Next time I will either use much larger or more tortillas or cut the recipe in half.  Tip: easy with the cayenne I put a tad too much and they were spicy.

text:
LOVE THEM! I am super happy because I really want to start cooking with less meat and more nutrition.  I served them to my beef&potato Dad and Uncle and they loved them too. (I didnt tell them what was in it until we were done lol) Anyhow, I am not a vegatarian and neither is anyone in my family so I suspected that i might miss the meat...NOT EVEN A LITTLE! This recipe is perfect just the way it is although I did not need to add the water to the beans.  I smothered mine with salsa and topped it with sour cream, fresh onions, and shredded lettuce (added texture) with a side of Spanish rice! Yummy! This will be a routine meal for sure! And HEALTHY! YAY! 

P.S. I have discovered that these are a little weird tasting if you just plop the potatoes and beans down and two separate piles.  They need to be smoothed out into layers for even distribution.

text:
I'm not a burrito fan but I do love sweet potatoes, so I thought I'd try these.  Glad I did, yum!  I mixed together the sweet potato and beans (I used black beans) all together and topped with a generous amount of cheddar cheese, then rolled up the burritos (I used Del Rey tortillas, which are my favorites).  I also drizzled with olive oil to add color and crispness to the tortillas when they were in the oven.  I used the recommended spice mix and that was good, added taste but wasn't overwhelming or too spicy (I don't like spice but if you do you might want to add some spice with a little more kick).

Display Name:
Jennifer Hilbrand Phifer
isPro:
