photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really wanted to like this recipe, but it just didn't come together like I wanted it to.  It's really more of a 3.5 as written, but it has potential. First of all, I used black beans as recommended by other users.  I also subbed in chicken broth for the water.  Next time I will save myself a WHOLE lot of trouble, and just buy refried black beans.  I second guessed using mustard & soy sauce in the beans, and now totally wish I hadn't.  In my opinion it threw the flavor off. Second, I added cumin, chili powder, butter, brown sugar, & cinnamon to the sweet potatoes before mashing them. Third, next time I will probably use a Mexican cheese & not cheddar. Like I said, great base for a recipe but way too many tweaks to give this four or five stars.

None
country:
None
text:
This is an interesting burrito.  I had some sweet potatoes to use up so I decided to give it a try.  It was an interesting combo of sweet and savory- which I like.  My bean mixture was a little watery (to watery to use as a filling) when I added the water.  I really needed to let that cook down a little before making the burritos.  I made half with colby jack and half with mozzarella (my husbands preference)  Next time I make these I will mix the potatoes and bean mixture together because even though I layered one on top of the other prior to wrapping up they seemed to separate in the burrito with one side being potato and the other black bean.   I can see why these are called addictive because the more you eat them the better they seem to taste so don't judge on the first bit alone.  Thanks for sharing.

country:

text:
These lived up to their "addictive" name.  I made them for dinner the other night, and after reading some of the reviews I substituted black beans for the kidney beans.  Other than that, I left the recipe as it was written.  They were DELICIOUS!  My 3 kids (2 adventurous eaters and one picky eater) were not big fans, but my husband and I couldn't get enough of these burritos.  I served them with salsa, fat-free sour cream, sliced avocado and cilantro all on the side.  I also served a black bean and corn salad with it. The next morning I realized why they are called "addictive" sweet potato burritos.  I opened the fridge to make breakfast and saw the leftovers.  I contemplated, then took one out, heated it in the microwave and had it for breakfast.  Even better than the night before.  I will definitely make them again. Oh - it also made way more than 12 burritos.  I probably could have gotten 15-18 out of the amount of potatoes and beans I had leftover.  Not a problem though....next time I'll make as many as I can and freeze them.

These were amazing.  Like other reviewers, I used 1 can of black beans, and I also used 1 can of pinto beans and some frozen corn.  I ran them under hot water and then mashed them. These are fabulous!  I used the modifications suggested by Toni below and used 1 can black beans, 1 can pinto beans and 1 cup frozen corn (thawed) as my bean mixture. text:
I gave these 5 starts, my huband gave 4! I love the combination of flavors. Here are the minor changes I made to work with what I had: -I used 2 cans black beans, 1 can kidney -I used 3 medium sized sweet potatoes With the  above amounts I got 10 burritos w/ a little bit of beans left over. -I didn't completely mash the beans so a 1/2c. water was just right. -I didn't use mustard, but loved the combination of the other flavors.  Like the recipe says, they do freeze well. I wrapped them in foil and then put in a ziploc bag. To reheat I just opened the foil a little and put in oven (I think at 375) for about 20 minutes. YUMMY!

text:
I loved these.  I'm not a fan of kidney beans so I used 1 can of black, 1 can of pink and 1 can of white beans.  I have a dairy allergy so I left out the cheese.    I didn't add water (didn't find that necessary), just mixed the sweet potatoes, beans and sauteed onions and spices.  I also added saffron brown rice to the mixture.  I may omit the brown rice next time, my husband said he would prefer without it.  These were so yummy AND healthy.  They're going in my monthly rotation.

text:
This recipe is one of my and my husband's favorite vegetarian burritos.  They are fairly easy to make, healthy, and wonderfully delicious.  Have made them many times.  Be careful not to add too much water or you will need to let it simmer off a while or add something like masa to thicken it.  We like to make the whole batch and wrap them individually, keeping them in the fridge for an instant, yummy lunch!

text:
this is seriously the strangest recipe i have ever made...it's just strange that these ingredients are together in this recipe.  i was really hoping this would be a good one to get my kids to eat more veggies, but it didnt go over very well.  the flavor was fine - nothing exciting and just kinda odd.  my husband said "interesting".  adding water to it really confused me as to why it was necessary - i added only half the amount indicated.  i would prefer not having the filling so loose and it would be better if it was thicker in the burrito and maybe less likely to squoosh out so much...so dont add water if thats your preference too.  i used refried black beans so there was no mashing and it was extremely easy to prepare.

text:
I didn't use the soy sauce, but added a 1/2 tsp. sea salt. I also didn't use the called for prepared mustard. I used a pre-mix seasoning pack (all natural) that I already had on-hand, instead of combining the spices myself. I added extra onion (sauteed), and used longhorn cheddar and jalapeno Jack cheddar combined. Topped with picante sauce, chopped tomatoes, and shredded lettuce. Put out bowls of chopped chives, jalapeno's and sour cream on the table for serving. Very yummy! (Also followed the advice of other reviewers and used black beans, not kidney beans).

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe and followed the directions as is.  I was rather concerned though with the bean mixture when I added in the water.  Mine was quite runny and didn't start to thicken at all until I added in the spices.  Even then, it was still runnier than I would have liked.  Next time I would reduce the water slightly, add in some peppers and/or other veggies.  I'd also bake a little longer so that the tortilla gets a little crispier and possibly add more amounts of spice.  All in all though, it was great and I'll do it again for sure.

text:
These were fantastic!  The only changes I made were substituting honey dijon mustard for the prepared mustard, and cajun spice blend for the cayenne pepper.  Also, I added only one cup of water at the end instead of two.  I felt that adding the other cup would make the mixture too runny.  I used a cheddar blend of cheeses, instead of cheddar only.  I can't wait to make these again!  These would please anyone, even the pickiest vegetarian!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Changed it put a bit but the concept is awesome. 1 can of black beans, heated with 1 garlic clove, pinch of curry powder and ground cumin and lots of chili flakes. 3 big sweet potatoes boiled with a clove of garlic, salt, pepper, paprika and mashed. Made about 7 or 8 good sized burritos, enough for 3 or 4 people. To assemble: I put a layer of beans, a layer of potatoes and some cheese on top. Folded it and placed on a lightly oiled sheet pan. Baked at 350 for about 10 minutes. I served it with sour cream, cilantro and a homemade pineapple salsa! Yuuummyy.

text:
I liked these, though I am going to tweak a little further. I did use black beans, and mashed them OUTSIDE the pot before adding. The amount of water was too much for the beans, so I will use half next time. Sauteeing the spices first seemed to make more sense. Next time I will add some oregano and coriander as well. Half a block of CREAM CHEESE, smeared on the tortillas before the other ingredients, was a REALLY good compliment, and we preferred this to the ones without them. In fact, the cream cheese could be mixed into the potato for richness and flavor. (I did not make this up; my favorite vegetarian restaurant is famous for a similar recipe).

text:
These are truly addictive!  

I follow the recipe except I leave out the chili powder (I don't like chili powder).

The first time I made this, I wasn't too sure about the first few bites.  But it grew on me and the next day, I was craving them again.  Thank goodness for leftovers.  My picky 5 and 8 yr olds like it too.

Some reviewers said the baking doesn't matter but I say it's essential!  Gives all the mushy potatoes and beans a little crunch.  I tried them once without baking (when I was in a hurry) and I'll never do that again...they still had great flavor but they do need that crunch!

Great recipe!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum!  This is a great recipe, although I am giving it 5 stars based on the following changes recommended by other users:  I used all black beans instead of kidney, used half called for water, added grilled veggies (onion, bell pepper and mushrooms), and lightly sprayed each burrito with cooking spray before baking to give it a more crispy,fried-like texture.  This recipe is quite a bit of work, but worth it becaue you get so many meals out of it.  I make a big batch, freeze left over burritos individually in a vaccuum seal bag, and microwave in a paper towel later for an quick easy meal.  I serve with avacado (if I've got it) and salsa.  Delish.

text:
"Wow" I made these for a dinner for a vegetarian and they were delicious!  We only managed one burrito each with salad because they were so filling.
I made a few changes which were use half and half black beans and kidney beans then mashed them up before adding to mashed sweet potatoes.  
I also sauteed the onions with garlic, chili powder and cumin then added the soy sauce and a little sugar, mixed all the ingredients together before filling the tortillas.
I also put, five minutes towards the end of cooking, some grated cheddar cheese onto the burritos before serving.  To say they went down a treat was an understatement will definitely be making these again.

Yum! This was so good...I love sweet potatos and this is a great (and unusual) way to use them.  I followed the recipe with one exception, I took the advice of another reviewer and added the spices to the onion and garlic to sautee and help release the flavors.  Other than that I followed to a tee.  The only thing I will change next time is how I asemble the burritos...I spooned the bean and potato mixture beside each other and it didn't mix enough.  Next time I will spoon the beans and potatos on top of each other so the flavors mix more.

text:
I've had this recipe in my box for 4-5 years and now I'm regretting that I didn't make it earlier!  I added the water to the beans before I added them to the pan and then I used my immersion blender to mash them -- this was super easy!  I used black beans instead of kidney beans.  Also - before I baked the burritos, I spread a thin layer of margarine on the top, baked them for 8 minutes and them broiled them for the rest -- the top became very toasted and delicious!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good!  I used canned sweet potatoes for maximum cheapness and speed, and mashed the beans with my mixer before they went into the frying pan with the garlic and onions.  Also, I only used one cup of water, but I'm pretty sure I had more than 4 cups of beans all told.  Just eyeball it - it should be a bean paste, not soupy!  Also, I used a very large frying pan, not a medium one... this is a large quantity of stuff to mix together!

Finally, I held the burritos together with toothpicks as they baked, so they kept their shape.

text:
Awesome!  My roommate made something like this once, and when I saw the recipe I had to try it.  I made a few minor changes:  I used all black beans--and after I had cooked the sweet potato, I put the beans and potato in my food processor and blended.  This was a huge time saver.  I also added almost 1/2 tbsp of cayenne pepper---which gave it a real kick.  When I sauteed the onions and garlic, I added a jalepeno and some green chile--which spiced things up.  The recipe made wayyyy too many burritos for me--so I wrapped the extra burritos in foil and put them in a container in the freezer.  I can pull one out and pop it in the oven if I'm running short on time!

text:
Wow, these are awesome! My husband was quite skeptical, since he doesn't LOVE sweet potatoes. But we loved them so much! I used a lot of the reviewers' tips (sauteed spices with the onions; mixed sweet potatoes into the black beans).  I used black beans instead of kidney, and whole wheat tortillas; reduced the chili to 2 Tbsp, and left out the cayenne, since we're not so into spicy. I baked 3 medium sweet potatoes (50 minutes at 350°) to make the mash; I also upped the cheese to 12 oz. This made about 18 burritos for us. So fantastic, and my 18-month old agreed!

This turned out really good. I cut the recipe in half and used 2 parts Black Beans, 1 part Kidney. The only complaint, preparing the cooked sweet potatoes took awhile.

text:
After reading the reviews, I decided to make this for my sister's family to freeze and serve later.  I used black beans instead of kidney beans and added a bit of cinnamon, clove and a touch of brown sugar to cancel the bitterness of the beans.  I also added silken tofu to the mashed sweet potatoes (for extra protein).  This made ten burritos.  Everyone LOVED these!  No one could tell there was tofu in it and my sister has begged me to make it again when I visit.  Next time, I will try them myself!

text:
Awesome recipe! I've made this many times for my family, my three-year-old asks for it often. I like to use half black beans and half red kidneys. I throw the mashed sweet potato in with the beans before filling the burritos just for convenience. They are very filling, and make a lot. I like to bake them (or use a countertop grill) and wrap the extra burritos in foil and freeze for an easy lunch. By the way, any extra filling can be used like refried beans, really good spread on a tortilla and fried with cheese quesadilla style. One of our favorite recipes of all time!

text:
These are pretty good. Not as fantastic as everyone else seemed to think and we LOVE sweet potatoes. One mistake I think I made was using the large tortilla wraps. They would definitely be better in a smaller size. Very good lunch option though. I loved how you can freeze them wrapped in paper towel, then micro them for lunches or a quick supper. This is a keeper.
Update: no - I prefer using these with large tortillas, but how I fixed my problem is that I just mix the potato in with the bean mixture before putting them in the tortillas. This solved the problem of getting one bite of beans then one bite of potato. I LOVE these. I'm never without them in the freezer for a meal on the go.

text:
Well....these could be good I suppose. The first problem I had was adding 2 cups of water to the beans...why? It would be soup! I was going to because I like following exact directions before reviewing but that would be too icky so I left out the water. I didn't want the beans seeping out everywhere. The second problem was the consistancy of the sweet potatoes after I baked them. I love them and give them to my kids just baked all the time but when you mash them, they need a bit of liquid in there. Otherwise not too appealing and not very spreadable inside a tortilla. So I added some evaporated milk to smooth them out a bit. This is a very odd recipe as it is. WAY too many beans per potatoes. Especially if you add 2 cups of water. I mananged to save this though but will make a few revisions if I make them again...IF I ever do. Just ho hum and the directions were somewhat weird.

text:
I read all the reviews and was hoping this would be a really good recipe. Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy these that much. The bean mixture was really good, I used black beans and kidney beans, mashed before hand. The sweet potatoes were just too much. I cut down the sweet potatoes in the burrito to maybe 1 Tablespoon because it was just too sweet against the spicy bean mixture. I loved the bean mixture and will use again but not with the sweet potatoes.

I was skeptical and looked at this recipe many times before I finally decided to try it. I would give it 3 1/2 stars because I tweeked it a bit and it could use some more. Added some cream cheese to the potato mash and extra cheese inside the burrito. Sour cream on top definitely made it tastier. Cilantro would be good in there next time. city:

country:
None
text:
I like burritos and sweet potatoes so I decided to try this recipe even though it did seem like an odd combination.  Another reason I decided to try it was because almost all of the reviews raved about the recipe.  

I was disappointed in the results.  The burritos didn't taste bad but I wouldn't describe them as "addictive" nor were they anything out of the ordinary.  I did follow the directions exactly EXCEPT I used canned sweet potatoes instead of fresh and I added the sweet potatoes to the bean mixture instead of layering it with the bean mixture on the tortillas.  One of the reasons I added the potatoes to the bean mixture was because the bean mixture was far too watery.  Inspite of the disappointing results, I may try these again--using fresh cooked sweet potatoes, cutting down on the water, and following the directions for assembling the burritos.  If the results are the same, however, I won't keep this recipe.

text:
These were very tasty! I ended up using almost equal parts of sweet potato and bean mixture. I tossed a splash of enchilada sauce into the potato mix. I also did not use water to the beans. I used salsa and some fat free half and half. It added the moisture that was needed and made it a bit creamy. I could imagine adding some cream cheese to either part of the filling to add some yum. This is a good basic idea. You can really make it what you like. It's going to be on the menu for next week! Thanks.

text:
i was a little hesitant to try these as i wasn't sure if my partner and i would like them.
but they were a pleasant surprise.
i scaled the recipe down to 4 servings but it could have fit into a couple more tortillas.
we added some salsa and sour cream to them after they came out of the oven as well and that improved the taste a lot. i don't think i would have liked them as much without that.
i also used black beans like others have suggested and then used a hand mixer since it was really hard to mash them. i probably won't add quite as much water to the bean mixture next time either.

None
text:
These are yummy. I did modify the recipe for my taste and for simplicity. I added the chili powder, cumin and salt to the onions and garlic. Then I added two cans of regular black beans without draining, as well as one can of refried black beans with jalepenos. I mixed this up, with no additional water, and then added the sweet potatoes. On top of that mixture i added a tub of spicy pico de gallo salsa. I omitted the mustard and soy sauce.Because I'd roasted the potatoes earlier in the week, this recipe went pretty quickly. The burritos were spicy and yummy, I made 12 and still had enough mix left over for bean dip.

Mmm... A very nice change from the basic/boring bean burrito! Will certainly make it again. Thank you for that different and tasty recipe! Changes: I saute the onions, and then blend everything (1 14oz can red beans 1 14 oz can sweet potatoes, rinsed). Top with cheese, roll in a tortilla, and lightly fry on both sides (or use no oil in a nonstick saucepan).

I am eating these for lunch right now 2 days after making them.  Would you believe the flavor is actually better today?  Even my kids said so! Adults, make sure you top it with the suggested sour cream, salso and green onions.  It tastes wonderful that way.  My kids told me this was one of the best veggie meals I have made! I omitted the mustard. I started to put it in, then I scraped it out as it smelled like a bad mix for our tastes.  I used canned sweet potatoes. I actually mixed the bean mixture with the potato mixture.  Enjoy this wonderful recipe!

I made these for a vegetarian friend and she loves them!  Since she is convalescing, I packaged them individually into freezer ziplock bags.  When she wants one, She takes the burrito out of the plastic, wets a paper towel, wraps the burrito in it and microwaves it for 1-2 min.  My husband and I are omnivores and we, of course, loved them too.  I made them just as the recipe suggested.  TWICE so far.  Delicious Fresh or reheated in the microwave.

I've made this recipe several times.  As writtten I give it 4 stars.  I prefer using black beans in place of the kidney beans.  And I don't completely mash them.  I like some chunks left for some texture.  I also like to use a flat out (or healthier tortilla wrap) than what was suggested.  This is definitely a go to, easy recipe I have made in heavy rotation.  Thank you for the recipe.

These also turn out great in the air fryer!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made an easier version of this recipe for 4 people. After sauteing the onion and garlic I added about  1/3 cup of water and mixed in peeled, cubed sweet potatoes along with chickpeas (which are easier to digest). I used more potato than peas. While it was cooking I graded cheese. When it was done, about 20 min later, I added 1/3rd of the rest of the ingredients and mashed it all in the same pan. We spooned the mixture into tortillas. Served it with the cheese, sour cream and salsa. Excellent vegetarian meal and the cumin gives it a wonderful flavor. Thank you for sharing.

region:

country:
None
text:
Oh dear Lord, these are good. I made the recipe exactly (except I only used about 1/4 c. water) and these were truly a religious experience. I've been putting off making these because I really thought the sweet potatoes would be too sweet and weird. They're not! Also, you may think adding mustard and soy sauce are the oddest thing ever, but these ingredients totally work and make the filling irresistible. The only negative thing I can say about this recipe is there is a very real danger of eating half of the filling out of the bowl while preparing the burritos. It takes A LOT of restraint. And need I state how healthy these are? I think I just did : )  I ate these with guacamole (although it isn't really needed.) Yummmmmmmmmy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was skeptical of this recipe, thinking it would be bland, and was so pleasantly surprised at how it turned out! Only did a few things different than the original recipe: 2 tablespoons of chili powder instead of three, cooked the onion first, released the flavor of the garlic by cooking it for a minute with the onion, then added all the spices to the onion garlic mixture to release the flavor of the spices. I added all remaining ingredients to the warm pan to mix, but omitted the water as I didn’t want the same mashed consistency of the potatoes for the beans. I only roughly mashed the beans once added so there was more texture. We froze the remaining burritos for lunches/snacks as needed so we’ll see how that turns out too!! Will definitely be making these again. I’ll probably add green pepper next time too

text:
I took the advice of some of the people that made this after reading  quite a few reviews.  I used 1 can of kidney beans & 1 can of black beans as this is what I had in my pantry.  I did not add any water to the beans. This would have made it too soupy.   One reviewer added chopped cilantro to the bean mixture and I did this also.  Good idea.   I was surprised at how well the mustard & soy sauce enhanced the flavors.  I will make this again.

When I saw this and wondered if these flavours could be good together.  I decided to go for it omitting the mustard and soy sauce which sounded terrible to me and am sorry to say no they don't .  Sweet potatoes and chili beans are not a good combination.  3 out of 5 of us ate it anyways because we don't waste food here.  I think this recipe must have come about  as a creative attempt to use what was left in the fridge so I gave an extra star for that it is creative.  You could do this with     russet potatoes and it would be good.  Also you do not need to drain your beans and add water.  I used two cans kidney and two cans chili flavoured red beans.

text:
I don't have canned beans where I live, so I prepare the kidney beans in a pressure cooker. I throw in the garlic and onion while cooking and then put them in a blender with the rest of the spices instead of mashing them. I use plain Greek yogurt as a sour cream substitute and sharp cheddar cheese. I put the burritos together while everything is hot and don't bother warming them up in the oven.

text:
If you are hesitant about trying these because they sound weird, well, they are.  I debated about making these because they sounded strange. But with all the glowing reviews, I figured there must be something magical in the combination of the sweet potatoes, beans, and spices that I was missing.  Well, there was nothing magical or addictive about these for us.  They just tasted like sweet potatoes...and...beans.  Not awful, but definitely nothing special and yes, strange.  I was surprised that with all the spices that I found they were a little bland.  I wanted to make these in an effort to get my kids to eat something healthier. They like sweet potatoes, they sort of like beans, and they love my cooking, but they HATED these.  They ended up eating frozen burritos instead. So much for my efforts. Won't be making these again. Sorry!

text:
Made these at the strong recommendation of a friend. I liked it but my kids didn't. This could be my fault as I followed the recommendations of the previous reviewers and used 2 cans black beans (rather than kidney), 3 large baked and mashed sweet potatoes, only 1 tsp chilli powder and no cayenne as I was out of it. I also added 1 can of corn (including the juice). I did mix the entire thing together too so it was one layer and less mess eating and assembling. Personally I liked the combo of beans and sweet potatoes and with the sour cream on top it was really good for me. Unfortunately I won't be making again anytime soon as the kids won't eat it. This made a ridiculous amount. I made 20 6in burritos and still had half the mixture left, when I ran out of cheese and tortillas.

text:
I love this recipe and have made it several times since finding it.  I think how well it turns out depends in part on the quality of your ingredients.  I use really good whole grain mustard and good spices and it's always very flavorful.  I also simplified the recipe a bit and I just cube the sweet potatoes,   toss in a small amount of olive oil, season with salt and pepper (and sometimes paprika) roast until crispy and use them like that.  It cuts down on the work of boiling and mashing and adds a nice texture  and smokey flavor.

text:
This recipe was great!  However I did make a few changes to it like everyone else.

I added 1 lb of ground beef, cooking that till brown first and then adding onion and garlic, following recipe.  

Then 2 cans kidney beans, and one can black beans.  

2 cups chicken broth

Then I peeled  & cubed the raw sweet potato and added it like that to the recipe.  I added all the spices except the mustard.

Then simmer on stove for 30 minutes, slightly smooch some of the recipe.  Then add to warm tortillas, put leftover sauce over tortillas and sprinkle with cheese.  Bake allotted time = YUM and easier

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Better than I expected. Followed the recipe, but was a bit low on chili powder. I also used half the amount of water as it seemed excessive, and per other reviewers I used black beans. I made an avocado cilantro sauce to go on top, which really made it great. If I make it again, I think I will mix the sweet potato and black beans together, omit the water, add sour cream into the burritos, add cilantro, and possibly add some smoked peppers. I might also use 12 inch tortilla shells. I would also double the amount of avocado sauce.

For anyone interested, the avocado sauce I made was just an avocado, 1/2 c water, 1/2 tsp salt, 3tbsp cilantro, 2 tsp olive oil, a clove of garlic, a pinch of pepper, and a tbsp lemon juice... just blended it until smooth.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2862128.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With the beans I put 2 cans of black beans 1 of chick peas and 1 of lentils. Mashed them up before I put it in the pan. Once in the pan I put 1/2 cup of chicken stock and about a cup of water and stirred it frequently. They were in the pan for about 15 min. Then I added all the seasoning while still in the pan.. Instead of cumin I put curry powder. And the other spicy thing I put just a little bit of paprika. Make sure you use normal mustard. I used Mexican four cheese. Also took advice and sprayed the parchment lappet with olive oil pan to make it a little bit crispy. The beans mashed by themselves with the spices  and a can of sweet corn make an exccelent bean dip. Also dsweet potato goes best with these.

Loved it!
I was looking for a recipe sans meat, sometimes i just want something different. I did make a few changes to match what i had on hand but i will be making it again for sure. I used a sweet potato and butternut squash since i had one that needed used up. Just threw them both in the microwave peeled and put them in with the onions, mashed them then i used a can of re fried beans since that's what i had. It was sooooo good! Even my husband that turned his nose up when he saw what i was doing ended up eating three. I baked mine with a little salsa on top with the cheese. I love being able to utilize fresh veg's, this was very filling as well.

My whole family loved these. Even my 13-year-old daughter who hates beans loved them. She said they tasted just like burritos to her. We have an entire pan for freezing and some left-over for lunches tomorrow. I used 3 cans black beans and 3 large sweet potatoes. Served with sour cream and and pico. I was very nervous about this, but so glad we gave it a go.

text:
Even the kids, who do not like sweet potatoes, REALLY liked this!  Two things I would do differently.  I would use less than the 2 cups of water as the bean mixture needed to be thicker.  I would also mix my sweet potatoes and the bean mixture prior to putting it in the tortilla so when you roll it up it is evenly mixed.  Many of our bits were just sweet potatoes.  But it was still GREAT!

city:

country:
None
text:
YUM!!!  I really loved this recipe!  It was a hit with my husband and 5 year olds also.  I used 6" organic whole grain tortillas so I had a lot of burritos.  They were just the right size for the twins.  I served with jalapenos, sour cream, salsa, and sliced avocados.  Some reviewers mentioned that mashing the beans, (I used black  beans by the way), was the hardest part.  I just used my potato masher right in the pan like the recipe said and had no problem.  You don't need to smash them so much that they are mushy.  I love this recipe because I have lots left over to freeze and use on a night when I don't have time to cook!!!

text:
I don't normally change a recipe the first time I try it, but tonight I had to.  I chose to use black beans instead of kidney, and since I was out of chili powder, I used spicy adobo chili powder.  My husband had recently smoked a pork shoulder, and we had already shredded it for barbeque.  So I added some of the pork to them, and assembled them like enchiladas.  I had some bean mixture left over, so I added water and poured that over the enchiladas. Baked at 350 for 30 minutes, served with sour cream and avocado slices.  Delicious!!

I made the recipe following the directions exactly and as such I give it 4 stars, next time I will make some changes. Mashing the kidney beans was difficult and really messy. I will use refried beans next time or just leave them whole.  I also found the water unnecessary and I just had to drain it off in the end. Finally I found it way too spicy but that is my taste, If you prefer things mild, skip the chili powder altogether or just add a pinch.

text:
I was a litte leary to try this because I've never tried this ingredient combination before.  But with all the good reviews, I decided to give it a go.  For some reason, I ended up having a lot of beans leftover.  The beans looked as though they had too much water and I had a hard time putting very much on the tortilla.  Good flavor though.  The sweet potato overpowered the beans (maybe because I did not use all the beans).  Maybe next time I will add less water and/or mix the potatoes in with the beans so that the flavor is more evened out.  Very filling, healthy, and inexpensive!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5713409.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Liked the sound of this recipe, made it as written, liked it but then made it with a few changes others may like also..
Diced onion, garlic and 1 jalapino all the same size with veggie chopper. Cooked in canola oil until soft, add 2 cans black beans drained, only 2T chili powder along with the cumin, 1T of mustard, omitted the cayenne but added 1T of cilantro along with the soy sauce. Diced the sweet potatoes in the same dicer added 2 cups of chicken broth instead of water to them and cooked in microwave until just getting tender...Added to bean mix and cooked until most moisture has evaporated then rolled with cheese and baked as directed...YUMMM

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was really surprised by how much I enjoyed this recipe.  Aside from greatly reducing the number of servings, I made this exactly as written.  I used one can of kidney beans, 1 large and two medium to small sweet potatoes (microwaved until soft, peeled and ran through a potato ricer).  For the spices, I reduced the serving number to 4 on the site and used those amounts (plus a little additional soy sauce).  I only had medium sized tortillas so I rolled them to the size of enchiladas and ended up filling a 9X13 pan.  My reductions made a meal for two with enough leftovers for my lunch.  Next time I will toast the spices for a couple of minutes with the onions and garlic prior to adding the beans and potato to develop the flavors.  I would definitely recommend giving this recipe a try!

text:
We love this recipe! I make a big pot of black beans which we eat fresh the first night and then I use the leftovers for this recipe. I always make extra and freeze the leftover premade burritos. We aren’t vegetarian, but i am happy to have a healthy non-meat dish my kids love! I leave out the cayenne because my kids can’t handle spicy food. They get excited when we have this and are happy to have a yummy standby in the freezer.

I was so excited to try these based on the reviews, but I just wasn't crazy about them.  The sweet potato was almost too sweet in contrast with the other ingredients.  I will say, though, that the kids liked them more than me.  If you make this, use larger tortillas - 10 inch was too small to roll well, either that, or make more than 12 of the 10 inch size or you will have way too much filling leftover.

text:
I have made these three times already, but have modified the recipe slightly - I placed two sweet and one baking potato in a ziploc bag, closed partially and microwaved to save time.  I used black beans and kidney beans because I love black beans and I omitted the soy sauce and added green salsa instead.  I didn't bake them at all either.  When I wanted to eat them, I just heated up a small portion and put it in a warm tortilla. Yummy!!!

None
text:
Yum!! I don't know what I thought, but I never thought these would taste as good as they do. I changed the recipe a little, just to fit what I had in the pantry. Mashed up some kidney beans, because I only had one sweet potato. Then added whole black beans. Running low on the spices I needed, so I just added my favorite hot sauce. Haven't baked these up yet, but the one I tasted was so delicious!

EDIT: After looking at this recipe again, I'm a little confused by the portions that the recipe calls for. I guess I only made 8 burritos, but I used one can of white kidney beans, mashed, and one can of black beans, whole. Plus ONE large sweet potato, which was about 1 1/2 cups. I'm not sure why you'd need so much filling as this was more than enough for 8 tortillas and I imagine could have filled 12. Still a fabulous recipe though!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe recently as a starter for a dinner party and it went down a treat.  However there was way too much chilli powder for the irish palate unfortunately and I had to scramble big time to rescue it when I tried it initially as there was no way we could have eaten it - I actually partially rinsed the beans in a sieve with fresh water to remove alot of the chilli-heat.  If making in UK/Ireland (or anywhere you're not used to eating "rocket-fuel" )- I'd suggest you start with 1 tsp of chilli powder and work your way up! Gorgeous recipe though and I will definitely make again (... with a qtr of the chilli powder recommended!!).

text:
These are awesome and also pretty quick. The longest thing was to peel, chop, cook and mash the potatoes!  I was a bit wary of the ingredients added to the beans so cut back mainly on the soy sauce and chili powder as I would rather use more cayenne pepper instead of chili powder next time (for a sweeter taste) and I also used less water. I used the kidney beans as directed but think it would be great with black beans too. So happy with these, great recipe! I also used Kumera instead of sweet potato.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe as is! I was curious about the odd combination of ingredients, but it comes together nicely and tastes fantastic. While cooking, I was concerned that the amount of liquid in the bean mixture seemed like way too much but it turned out fine the way I assembled the burritos. First,  I spread some of the sweet potato mixture onto the tortilla, then added the bean liquid on top of the sweet potatoes, then a little cheddar cheese. After folding them burrito style, I used the leftover bean mixture to pour over the top, then added more shredded cheddar. I served the burritos with sour cream and Near East brand spanish rice. Thank you so much, this was a great recipe Karena! :)

text:
I suggest this recipe for those who like sweet entrees. I didn't like the sweet potato portion of this recipe (it's not bad, its just a personal preference) but I really liked the bean part and when I make this recipe in the future I will eliminate the sweet potato (I might try it with regular potato).  Changes: I used black beans instead of kidney beans like the others suggested but I didn't have enough so I used 1/3 chickpeas as well. I also only used 1 cup water and used a hand blender to mix the beans/chickpeas/onions/garlic mix. This recipe makes more bean mix than sweet potato so you can't really do half half with each mix.

Like others, I was a bit nervous to give it a try......glad we did.  Somehow I was out of Chili powder so I added curry instead and a little salt (had low sodium soy sauce). Must be catching on, Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives had bean and sweet potato burritos on their eppisode last night.  We'll definately be making this one agian, thanks Karena!!!!

text:
Truly addictive. I have over a dozen in my freezer. They're best fresh from the oven, but they microwave well for a very easy and healthy lunch.   I've made the recipe over a dozen times. It is great as is but it is also very forgiving. My favorite version is to make a pot of curry couscous with chopped and sauteed onion and bell pepper added to the couscous. Then add the sweet potato mixture, couscous and cheese to each burritos. Better and healthier than anything at Chipotle. Black beans and corn instead of the kidney beans are fantastic too.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1213695.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were a great no-meat burrito with plenty of flavor. My kids (12, 9 and 7) even surprised me by liking it. I followed the recipe with the exceptions listed below.I added more cheese than called for (I always do in Mexican dishes). All of the following changes were suggested by other reviewers: I used all black beans, as well as heating the powdered spices in the skillet for a few minutes to release their flavors. Mashing the beans in the skillet with a potato masher makes the job easy. I also made it as a casserole (seemed easier), and reduced the liquid by half. I think next time I'll keep the casserole format, but increase the liquid to the full amount just to see what happens. It was a little dry.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love these burritos! My changes: I always used black beans and whole spelt tortillas. YUM! If you're looking for alternative ways to cook with sweet potatoes, try these! tonight!  edit: These can have a mushy texture so I came up with a "corn relish" to add to the burrito to add some crunch to it. It's a great addition to these burritos!!!  1/4 c frozen corn, 2-3 TBSP diced minced onion, 3 TBSP diced bell pepper, 1 1/2 TBSP honey, glug of balsamic vinegar, salt & pepper. Combine in a bowl, let sit while you make the burrito filling, then add to burrito before you wrap it up.

This was very yummy and different.  I was pleasenty suprised that I liked it so much.  I agree with others that it is hard to mush the beans after they go into the pan, I ended up dumping the beans, onion and all into the food processor to mush.  The sweetness of the sweet potato went great with the tangyness of sour cream.  This is definately going into my go-to-dinners cookbook.  I wanted to use blackbeans instead of kidney beans but didn't buy enough, so I used a mix.  It turned out great.

text:
Soy sauce and mustard in a burrito? Sweet potato?  With all the rave reviews, I had to try these.  I'm glad I did.  Really good. I cut the recipe in half.  I used one can of refried beans and only about 1/4 a cup of water and no cumin. After I baked them I served with salsa and sour cream.  I thought they were great and husband said they were good but not great.  I think I will try with a bit less sweet potato next time. I don't try to roll these burrito style. I just fold two sides of the tortilla over the filling and secure with a toothpick.

text:
I love this idea- sweet potatoes in a burrito sounds weird at first, but it is SO delicious.  I make it with black beans- personal preference.  Sometimes, instead of rolling these up into flour tortillas, I'll use corn tortillas and make little pies with them. I mash the sweet potatoes, then I layer one corn tortilla with sweet potato, black beans and cheese, put another tortilla on top and layer it again.  I then bake them at 425 for 7-8 mins until they're a bit crispy. And either way, I always serve this with fresh avocado.

I admit I was a little skeptical of this recipe, but I am so happy I made them anyway. These were a hit with the whole family! It is very hard for me to get my husband to eat anything without meat and he really liked these. It made so much that I had enough for lunch three days in a row! text:
I was very leery of this recipe, but decided to give it a try anyway.  I chose this for dinner last night, cutting the recipe in half as there are only two of us in my home.  I figured I'd have plenty left for lunch for a couple of days.  NOPE. My husband ate 3 full burritos, he just kept going back for more.  I managed to salvage enough to make lunch for the two of us today. 

I do think there is plenty of filling that I could have made 8 burritos instead of just 6 the the halved recipe called for.  The filling literally spilled out.  I think I'll try black beans next time. I did it with pinto beans this time, but there is always room for improvement.

We try to do a couple of basically vegetarian meals each week, and this is one I will repeat.

city:

country:
None
text:
I've been making these for a couple years now and everyone just loves them. I bake my sweet potatoes for 2.5 hrs on low before starting w this recipe. (They're usu left over baked sweet potatoes from a previous meal.) Use a potato masher on the beans. I combine the kidney bean mixture and sweet potatoes together before filling into burritos. I also prepare extra grilled onions to fill the burritos. I top the burritos w enchilada sauce and cheese, then bake. Fabulous! Even people who do not like beans enjoy these. Makes a wonderful 'bean' dip too.

This was pretty good but I'm giving it a three because I really felt like the potatoes were too sweet and overpowered everything else. It wasn't a great flavor combo.  The bean mixture was the BOMB!!  I used all black beans but other than that followed the recipe and my son and I were eating them with a spoon out of the pan.  Next time I'll do just the beans with the fixings.  This makes ALOT of food, I had 6 huge burritos so depending on your need you might want to cut the recipe down.

text:
Delicious. I doubted whether or not I would like these but they were sooo good. I made the six cups of kidney beans myself, in the crockpot and then I mashed them using the food processor before adding them into the onions. I only added in 1 cup of water, which in my opinion was not even needed since my beans were already kind of liquidy. I followed the rest of the recipe as stated except I used 2 parts bean mixture and 1 part mashed sweet potato for every burrito. Used whole wheat tortillas and served them with guacamole, sour cream, salsa and stir fried veggies (I used green & red peppers + broccoli). Would make these again, even my picky brother loved these, thanks.

text:
The food turned out AMAZING...but getting there was more difficult than I had planned. I didn't know how much work was involved in mashing sweet potatoes...I put them in the microwave for about 13 minutes, cut them in half, and then scooped out the inside. I also didn't know how many potatoes it would take--I used 5 BIG ones and it was a bit too much. By the time I had finished with the potatoes, I didn't do much bean mashing (I used black beans...like 5 cans.) They were fine not mashed. I don't know why it calls for 2 cups of water...after one the mixture was all soupy! I only put in 2 tablespoons of chili powder because I feared the spiceness, but I should have used all 3. Its wasn't enough spice. Instead of putting together burritos, I just layered everything in a pan: tortilla, beans, potatoes, cheese. I was SO worried about how it was going to taste...BUT IT WAS DELICIOUS. Four girls...and we almost ate it ALL!!!

text:
This is worthy of earning a spot in my rotation.  Very filling.  I totally agree with those who recommended that the onion/garlic saute' include the spices as it gives the opportunity for the flavors to blend vs. adding them afterward.  Eyeball the amount of water and decide what works best re the desired consistency.  I scaled recipe to 4 and didn't use all of the recommended 2/3 cup of water.  The other nice thing about this recipe is it's obvious flexibility - I'm going to experiment with other spices.  I added just a touch of curry powder and it was a great addition.  I could make a meal on the bean mixture alone!

text:
These are soooo good. I don't recommend removing from heat before adding spices though, it will be really watery. Add your spices and let it all simmer until you have a nice thick mixture. Also, don't worry about mashing the sweet potatoes, just microwave them and cut them into cubes - I also sprinkle them with a little cinnamon.

userID:
2348670
Display Name:
handbanana
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Having a newborn baby at home I looked for an easy recipe with ingredients I had on hand and found this one.  The fact I could eat with one hand was an extra bonus!  I totally simplified this recipe due to time contraints and not being able to eat anything spicy at all or else the baby is upset all the next day.  The changes I made to serve 2 adults are: 1 can refried beans with about 1/2 cup of water, 2 sweet potatoes microwaved until soft, cumin, soy sauce, and mustard, I eyeballed the last 3 ingredients.  I warmed the beans, water, cumin, soy sauce, and mustard on the stovetop until warm then added sweet potatoes.  I stirred until blended and put directly into flour tortillas.  Then added a little bit of both cheese and sour cream, rolled them up, and microwaved for 30 seconds.  Husband said was a little bland but he understands why since I am breastfeeding.  For his second burrito I added lettuce and tomato.  We both really love this fast meal and will make again soon.  I liked mine better without cheese.  Thanks to all the other reviewers who encouraged altering this recipe safely.  It would be really hard to mess this one up.  It isn't sweet at all and I only had one pan to wash!

text:
I made these today for my daughters to have in the freezer...they are vegetarian and my husband and I are not. I had to try one of course to check seasoning and decide if I would ever make again.  I do not like sweet potatoes but I thought these were delicious!  I was very pleasantly surprised considering how very easily they came together.  I threw black beans, kidney beans and canned cut up sweet potatoes in the food processor and pulsed until it was all mashed but still retained some texture. Next time I think I'll brush the tops with some vegetable oil before putting into the oven to help brown the tops since they were a bit pale.  Excellent recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like others, I debated trying this recipe for quite awhile before I decided to try it out for dinner tonight.  It was good and worth making again with a little more tweaking.

I cooked the sweet potatoes with a couple of whole cinnamon sticks that added a delicious aroma and nice taste.  I followed the advice of others and added just enough water from the cooked sweet potatoes to give it the right texture.  I added some pumpkin pie spice, maple syrup and balsamic vinegar to the sweet potatoes and stirred them into the bean mixture.  I served them with cheese, sour cream, cilantro, and a black bean and corn salsa.  I think that next time, I'll leave out the mustard (overwhelming taste) and add more spices.

Nice contrast of flavors and not too much hassle to make.  Being a beginner I followed the recipe (except for using black beans).  I found the burritos a little bland, but with sour cream and salsa they tasted great.  Next time I will likely add more spice during the prep. I made these for my writing group and they were a HUGE hit. I pretty much followed the recipe-- but I did make the sweet potatoes with some butter, a little sugar and cinnamon. They came out wonderful and I had so many extras I sent people home with a couple each (and I have tons left for myself).

I give these 4 stairs only b/c they were a little too labor intensive for me to make often. Peeling the sweet potatoes, boiling them, and then cooking the beans and filling the burritos was a lot to do in my little kitchen!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were addictive...who would've thought?  I altered this a bit...used black beans instead of kidney.  Sauteed onion and garlic, and added a chopped green chile.  Then I added chili powder, cumin and a little cayenne to the pan, followed by the beans.  I mashed them slightly and added just a little bit of water (maybe 1/2 cup).  Then I added in some cilantro and lime juice.  I did not use soy sauce or mustard (that just sounded too weird).  I served the burritos with a little light sour cream and salsa verde...they were delicious!  THey are definitely going into the rotation at our house.

These were pretty good, very filling, and pretty easy to prepare.  I was  excited to find a recipe that moved away from meat and instead had a healthy alternative like sweet potatoes.  I  used whole wheat tortillas and black beans.  The end reult was definitely different than what I'm used to, but was still really good - and I don't like sweet potatoes very much. I think the only change I would make it to add more texture - it was too smooth inside the tortillas, almost a pureed feel. Maybe next time I'll try mashing the beans less and see if that helps.  All in all a very good recipe - I'll be making this again.

text:
This recipe caught my eye as it is sweet potato (satsumaimo) season here in Japan.  I halved the recipe and used a can of refried beans in place of the kidney beans.  I was a little worried about the amount of chili powder, so I halved it, and even then it was far too spicy for my husband and I.  I'm not sure about the mustard flavour myself, but my husband had no complaints.  I would make this recipe again, but would definately adjust the spices.

text:
Loved 'em!  The addition of the mustard and soy sauce seemed odd, but the burritos tasted great.  I forgot to add the cheese inside the burritos, so I sprinkled it on top with some fresh cilantro.  It made for a great presentation.  I added the full cup of water...you just have to make sure the beans are mashed a bit and cook 'em long enough to absorb the water.  I used sweet potatoes (not yams) and added them to the bean mixture before filling the burritos.  Because I was skeptical of the recipe, I only made half (which made 8 burritos).  Next time I'll make the whole amount!

text:
I first tried this recipe a few years back, and thought it was a nice change of pace from usual vegetarian fare. Since then, the beans from this recipe have become a staple in our diet. I serve them with regular burritos, over rice with cheese, onions, salsa and sour cream, as an accompaniment for fajitas, and also as a base for homemade chili. Any combination of light or dark kidney beans or black beans can be used.  I always get raves.

text:
I have made this meal dozens of times.  We all love it.  We eat them as tacos instead of baked burritos because it's faster.  Stab the sweet potato a few times and stick it in the microwave for a few minutes, warm up homemade frozen black beans and this becomes very very fast and excellent.  We usually just have them with salsa, sour cream, and cilantro instead of the soy sauce mix, for a more traditional taste.

text:
This was a major hit at my house.  My husband dislikes sweet potatoes - and he loved it too.

It made me realize I could eat vegetarian and not even miss the meat (or chicken).  I did have difficulty mashing the beans.  And, I used buena vida fat free tortillas, which evidently were not big enough because I had a lot of filling left over.  Additionally it was not possible to fold them due to the smaller size.  So I spread the leftover filling on top of the tortillas and sprinkled extra cheddar over everything.  Really it was more like I made the recipe into enchiladas.  But we will be eating this meal regularly.  I would recommend to anyone.

text:
Yummy recipe. I don't eat meat so this was the perfect recipe for me. Mashing the kidney beans wasn't much fun, but the result was a delicious burrito, although I did add some extra spices to the beans for flavouring. It made at least 12 meal sized burritos, perhaps more. I wrapped and froze them individually and microwaved them as needed for a quick lunch or dinner. Will definitely use it again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm in love! Great recipe! Easy to pull together (with a side of saffron rice, perhaps), and great for preparing ahead of time. A few tips to make it even easier: Microwave the sweet potatoes until soft (about 15 minutes), then just scoop them out onto the tortillas. I have also substituted  refried beans when I ran out of kidney beans. No mashing, and they give it a slightly different flavor and texture. I have a freezer full of them right now for quick lunches and dinners.

region:

country:

text:
I liked the recipe.  I didn't try it on my husband or kids, because none of them like sweet potatoes.  I cut them in half and freeze them, and they make a nice, filling no-meat lunch.  I used canned kidney beans, drained, and the amount of water was right.  Had to use canned yams, because no fresh were available.  I haven't tried canned re-fried beans, but I don't think the taste of sweet potatoes would go with pinto beans as well as with kidney or black beans.
